element_texts.text: Completed

Antoinette Dunbarton Hill
Nov. 4-11
Jonesboro, Nov, 26. 1857
Tuesday Eve, - 4th Nov,, 1857
My dear friends, -
Yours of Oct. 19, reached me to day and to night, as I recount the unnumbered blessings that surround me, my heart is full of gladness, and, I trust, of true gratitude, to the giver of every good and perfect gift. My dear parents, who have both been laid aside by disease, seem now to have regained their wonted health, and can engage as usual in their customary duties and labors, and your letter just arrived, brings the glad news of your own returning health and strength, so how can I but rejoice? Truly, God "is good to all, and his tender mercies are over all his works."
I am very glad you are gaining the lost pounds, and hope you will not be disturbed by any return of the Ague. I presume you may be as well as usual during the winter months. But -- shall fear, if you stay longer than this that you will have some unwelcome visits. I judge thus from my own ex-
margin
I believe I will direct to Jonesboro, as I did my last letter, though I hardly know which is safest, or wh. direction would enduce the quickest arrival: Mt. Hawkins or Jonesboro.
Completed

experience. I never was more perfectly well, than during the winter in Illinois, but, with the coming of spring, the disease returned with as much violence as ever. I know this is not the case with all, and you might be among the fortunate; but would it be best to run the risk! I do think a healthier location very desirable, and I really cannot endure to think of your spending another season in Illinois. Monday, Nov. 10 - Almost a week since I began writing - but - it has been a busy one; and moreover, I did not feel so much in haste and sometimes, because I had dispatched a letter only a few days before yours reached me. I think they come here pretty regularly, as a general thing, usually reaching me about two weeks from the date of mailing. There were but nine days between the last two, and, as four weeks is the usual time, I almost feared to open it, lest it should tell me something sad, but I could not wait, and was very soon rejoicing to find all well. I am hoping now to hear in two weeks. This will make the long distance between us, seem twice as short. Perhaps, ere this, Col. Reason? and the newly appointed Engineer have arrived, and you relinquished the
Completed

honors, with the vexations too, of your station. $3000,00 is indeed a large salary - more perhaps than could be obtained in New. England - But the care? must be considerable, and, as you say, in loosing so great pay, you escape the burden of responsibility also, so never mind the loss, but "hope on". - It is evening, as it usually is when I sit down to write, and we have just finished family devotions. We usually sing, and to night we sung the evening hymn commencing, "The day is past and gone". O these are precious seasons. I shall never, never forget them, go where I may - But our circle is more broken than usual to night. So it makes us who are left draw closer together. Mother has become so well that she had left us, and gone to visit her relatives in Westboro, Mass., and it seems as if half the brightness of our home is gone. She went thus suddenly, chiefly because of a sick sister, whose health it was thought might be benefitted by her presence. She is exceedingly nervous, and mother, though never well herself, is a very cheerful body, and perhaps will drive the "blues" away from Aunt Martha. It is possible she may come back with mother, and try the effect
Completed

of a change of air, and scene, upon her health. Mother will probably be away three or four weeks, and right glad I shall be when she returns to us, for it seems lonely enough without her. We have been having more snow to day - the ground is perfectly covered again, but the storm seems to be over now and it is growing wintry-cold. I do not know whether, or not I have told you that father has purchased the whole of "Abbotts Lives" of Histories, so that we are finely provided with interesting reading for the long evenings. Father comes out and sits with us, while we read. We have finished "Cyrus", "Darius", and "Xerxes", and have commenced "Alexander the Great". We enjoy these readings very much. I wish you could be with us. We sit around the table, the fire burning brightly before us, the tea kettle singing, and pussy purring in the corner, looking up very wisely now and then, to show her interest in the subject. There, father has come this moment with the book in his hand, ready to begin reading - so I must stop now, and finish this in the morning. 11th ; Morning has come, and a glorious one it is. The snow-covered ground sparkled like the starlit sky of evening; and churches and quiet dwellings, hills, valleys, and distant mountains are all luxuriating in the golden sunlight. Father has gone to visit a school, and Jenny has gone too, to enjoy the first sleighride. I must write a letter to mother to go by to day's mail, so with much love, and my kindest good morning, I close. Father and Jenny send love. Yours, ever truly, Antoinette.
Completed

margin I hope you hear good news from Maine. How do your mother and sister feel about your remaining in Illinois! Sometimes I hope you will not stay - but perhaps I ought not to. I presume all will be directed for the best. Father and mother send love. Yours ever in love, Antoinette.
Home, Nov. 22, 1857
Jonesboro Dec. 8, 1857
My dear friend, - Yours of the fifth inst. lies before me. It has been just about two weeks in coming and it does sum good, I assure you to get a letter so soon. I am sorry the mails are so irregular with you, and that it takes so long a time for news to reach you from the East. I do not think Southern Illinois is a very favorable situation, and I shall be glad as I presume you will, to have you located more pleasantly and comfortably. You must have had a disagreeable and discouraging summer and Autumn, and I do hope matters will be so arranged that the winter may be one of health and happiness. i do not think you would be be deprived of so may privileges, in the Northern part of the state. Dear mother has come home this afternoon from her visit to Mass. I believe I wrote in the last letter that she had gone. She has been away
Completed

about three weeks. She endured the journey & the visiting very well, and thinks she has gained some strength. The riding has fatigued her so she does not feel very bright this evening. She says she is glad to get home, and we are all most certainly glad to have her. I only wish you were here too, to help us be happy. How I should enjoy it! Mother has talked to us, as much as she was able, about the friends she has seen, and little incidents of her journey; and we have told her as much as we could what we have been doing at home, and what has occurred during her absence. And then I have been singing for father and mother some of their favorite hymn and chants, and now it is past nine o'clock, and I am left all alone. This is the time when I write most of my letters - after nine in the evening. A letter from George came to day. His term is now through, but he is spending vacation at Meriden, and employing the time in studying music. He is at the same Academy father attended when fitting for College, and I was thinking a few days since, how very differently they were situated. Father decided to commence studying, left the trade he was
Completed

thus learning, and with a small bundle under his arm containing his all of books, or clothes, he walked one hundred miles from his home in Sutton, mass, to the Academy. He was the seventh of a poor, widowed mother's eight sons. He had poverty and ill health to contend with, through his whole course of study. But he found some of the very best of friends, wherever he went, who did all for him that kindness could dictate. George, I suppose would be classed among the poor boys, but he is certainly very comfortably situated, when we compare his case with father's. In the cars, with his well filled trunks, he could have seemed rich to the lone, pennyless boy, bearing his scanty wardrobe, and counting the weary hours, on foot. But father says he enjoyed himself finely all the while he was studying. He was rich in friends. But I must stop here - it is too late to write more to night. Sabbath evening, Nov. 23} I have just finished writing in my "Sermon book", what I could recollect of to-days discourses, and happened to think you might be interested in a piece of a Congregational Sermon, for a change; so I will venture to send you an outline of fathers sermon.
Completed

this afternoon as I have it - in my book -. Text - Col. 2:10. "And ye are complete in him, which is the head of all principality and power". Theme - Those who receive Christ - will have their highest wants supplied. Consider man's wants. Consider the fact that those who receive Christ will have every want completely supplied. Man's wants. 1. He wants saving knowledge. Man has knowledge by which he can make the rivers his road, and the ocean his highway. He can measure the distance to the sun and the starts, and make the lightenings of heaven do his bidding. He can weigh the hills in scales and the mountains in a balance. He possesses powers and faculties which fit him to be a companion of angels, and yet he needs that knowledge which will save the soul. All else is vain. 2. Man needs justifying righteousness. No one can obtain this by his own merits. 3. He needs the aids of the Holy Spirit. 4. He needs an Almighty Friend, to protect him against the evils which encompass him. 5. Man wants a home in Heaven. He know how dear is an earthly home and how we pity the poor wanderer who has no home. No home in all this wide, unfriendly world! Well may we love our earthly home; but we need a home beyond the skies, when the turmoil of life shall be past. Consider the fact, that those who receive Christ, will have every want completely supplied. Do we need saving knowledge? Christ can impart it. He is the medium of communication between God and fallen man. The word was made flesh and dwelt among us. Do we need justifying righteousness? Christ is the end of the law to everyone that believeth. Do we need the aids of the Holy Spirit? Christ has promised his followers that he will send them the Comforter, which is the Holy Ghost. Do we need an Almighty friend? Christ is such. He has all power in Heaven and on earth; and he has said he will never leave nor forsake those who trust in him. Do we need a home in heaven? Christ will provide us this. He says, "In my Father's house are many mansions. I go to prepare a place for you". The sermon closed with an application of the subject - both to the professed followers of Jesus, and to the unconverted. Monday eve - Nov. 24. This is a cold, uncomfortable evening. I have just come in from a meeting of the choir. We are preparing some pieces to sing Thanksgiving day. I suppose it will be long after Thanksgiving before you get this letter. I hope it will be a pleasant day to your
Completed

Antoinette  December 1851 Dunbarton
Jonesboro, Illinois, January 1852
Home, December 2, 1851
My dear friend - 
The  last mail brought your letter of November 20 and made my heart glad.  I really do not know what I should do without the letters.  They do a world of good.
I rejoice that your health still continues to improve, and hope you will not venture to remain so late in the Spring as to turn the scale.  I should feel so thankful if you can come back from the West well.  I supposed it would be next to impossible for me to come East from Illinois after the Lake navigation closes.  As you say, it seems you must remain for the winter, then there is no other alternative.  When ti projected railroads shall be completed, this difficulty - about winter traveling will be entirely obviated, I suppose.
Well, I hope you will enjoy the winter very much and I shall be "happy at home" unless the storms
Completed

King or some other evil genius intercept the letters or delay their coming.  But I suppose it would be as well not to anticipate trouble from this source, but cheerfully expect the best.  I believe no letter has failed, as yet.  So judging of the future by the past, none ever will.  I do not wonder that you are lonesome so very far from dear home, and dearer friends.  Be these winter months will pass away rapidly and March will come almost before we think of it.
We have been having fine snow storms without any wind to make it drift, and this morning the rain has been falling very softly upon it.  But the clouds are now parting and the sun and blue sky peeping out between them in every direction.  However, it is growing cold and freezing so our snow will be furnished with a "coat of mail" that the wind cannot move.  We always feel very gad of a snow without a blow.  We had a snow storm too, just before Thanksgiving, but the day was a glorious one and the sleighing fine.  A great many people were at meeting.  But it hardly seemed like Thanksgiving to us.  We were alone til just about night.  Then some of the young people of the neighborhood
Completed

came in unexpectedly, and spent a part of the evening.  It is just about a year now since I left home for Merrimack, to be a school girl again.  I remember that term with a great deal of pleasure.  It was a sunny spot in my life which it will always be happiness to review.  And I am constantly find the benefit of it in many respects.
I think you must have enjoyed the meeting of the Sabbath Convention very much.  I noticed the fact you mention, in regard to ministers originally from the East. acquiring or adopting so fully a Western style of oratory.  There was one exception to this however.  There was one minister who made me forget on the Sabbath that I was not in New England.  It was Mr. Porter, then of Lockport.  He is still in  Illinois, though he had left that place.  Perhaps he was among the company of ministers at Jonesboro; though I believe his location is not so far south.  I suppose some of these Western preachers are very needy.  When I read their statements in the Form Missionary of the pressing want  of laborers and funds and in many cases, the story of real suffering in their families.  I think of an expedition I once
Completed

read, "O, if I were rich, what a big present I would make you."  But it is a pleasure to make little presents to those so worthy, and a privilege too -- a precious one.
Will your duties this winter occupy your time wholly, or will you have more leisure for yourself at this season?
There comes Jenny from school, full of fun and frolic as she can be.  I presume she will not permit me to be sober enough to write much more.  She always expects a play when she comes from school and if I am busy and 'sober', as she calls it, she besieges me till I am forced to surrender.  We had a "Common School Convention" last week, at which the County Commissioner was present and, in the evening, lectured.  We visited two schools in the forenoon of the day he spent in town.  One of them in this district.  The meetings were very interesting and we we think will do good, especially in leading people to think more of the importance of moral character in selecting teachers.  Have they schools in the region where you are located?
Six long weeks at least before I shall receive an answer to this letter.  How long it takes us to talk!  But your last was two days less than a fortnight in coming from Illinois here.  But I must stop.  Please say in your next whether you hear from Maine frequently, and if all are well.
Much love from all,
Even yours most truly,
Antoinette
Completed

Dunbarton, December 19, 1851
Your letter of November 30 came in due season, and though it is somewhat late to night, to think of writing, I believe I must make a beginning.  I have been wishing you were here this evening.  I seems as if I should have considerable to say to you, but perhaps if you were really here, I could scarcely utter a syllable.  I am very apt to do my talking, as Washington did his laughing (inside).
This is a lovely evening, and it succeeds a glorious day.  Father went to make calls this afternoon, and as mother did not feel quite well enough to go out, I went with him.  The sleighing is remarkably fine, and the blue sky to day is perfectly cloudless. So with father for company I enjoyed the ride much, and the calls also.  This evening I have been reading to father and
Completed

mother about Kossuth.  Our last paper contains an abstract of Charles Summer's speech in Congress in regard to him.  We are all very much interested in whatever pertains to Kossuth, of course.
I read some railroad notices too, one of which father thinks I had better copy for you, though it may be you have known about it already.  It is in relation to the "Air Line Railroad" between New York and Boston and is as follows - "The subscription to the New-York to Boston (on Air Line) Railroad, exceeded on the 12 of December inst., one million of dollars, a sum required to be subscribed by that day to prevent a forfeiture of former subscriptions, made on that condition.  This, it is supposed, will ensure the construction of the road."*
We were thinking the line of the road, might furnish a pleasant and healthy location.  Will the failure of this 15 million loan from England, for the Illinois Central Road, make any difference in regard to the progress and completion of the Road?

Another paragraph in the same paper says the work is soon to be put under contract.
I was much interested in what your last letter tells me of the churches and preaching in Jonesboro, and of the manner in which your
Completed

time is occupied on Sabbath, and through the week.  I should like to know what you do for dinner when you spend whole days in the woods.  Do you carry baskets of dinner, and spread a table among those tall trees?  I should think you might have grand picnics in the summer season, when out in the woods for the whole day.
Sabbath evening -- Perhaps you are attending an evening service now, either Baptist, Methodist, or the "good old German".  Last Sabbath we were addressed by an agent in behalf of the Jews.  I have thought more than ever within a few weeks of this most interesting class of people, because I have been reading the prophecies in the Bible respecting them.  How exactly and strikingly they have been fulfilled thus far.  We were told last Sabbath that there had been 20 conversions to Christianity in this country among them in the last year.  There is one thought, in reference to them, which never occurred to me before.  The vast amount of which they can accomplish when converted to Christianity the world, scattered as they are among all nations, accustomed to every variety of climate and speaking all languages.
Completed

(December 23, Tuesday)  We are just having a great snow storm and it does look rather dreary out of doors. Mother says it seems rather sad to her because she cannot go out after the very cold weather, and deep snow come she cannot walk at all on the snow, and she seldom rides in winter, except across the Common to Church.  She is about as well as usual now.  She has had two or three sick days since I wrote last in consequence of over exertion.  She is a very industrious body, and when she feels particularly well, is apt to go beyond her strength.  Father says she never had a lazy bone, nerve or muscle.
Brother George was very well when he wrote last.  He told us how he spent Thanksgiving.  He accepted an invitation to pass the day at the home of one of his school mates, and had a pleasant time, though he said he could not help thinking of home, and wishing he could be with us.  How strange it would seem as you say not to have any Thanksgiving, or not to miss anything about it.  I should infer from a paragraph in a newspaper, that the Pennsylvanians had never observed the day till this year.  I should suppose that as a general thing, in the Middle and Western States, they observe Christmas and New Years more than the Puritan's Thanksgiving.
I do not know but letters will come all the quicker for the winter winds and storms - at any rate, that seems to have been the effect thus far and I mean to think it will be so till proof comes to the contrary.
Father and mother say I must always give you their love, so here it is with some from your ever affectionate
Antoinette
Completed

Antoinette   Dunbarton New Hampshire
January 3
Jonesboro, February 6, 1852  Dunbarton third January, 1852 - 
My dear friend,
Two days have passed since I welcomed your kind letter, but company and many duties have prevented me from commencing a reply till now.  My time has been rather unusually occupied this week.  Monday forenoon I was washing as usual.  In the afternoon, my dear mother and I had a nice cozy time by ourselves, sewing and talking - father busy in the study and Jenny at school.  In the evening, father came out and reading and conversing of what we read occupied us till past nine o'clock.  We were reading a History of "William the Norman".  Tuesday my friend Miss Burnham came to see me and a good long chat we had. At two in the afternoon, went to attend an Anti Slavery concert.  We have a stated meeting of this kind every month, at which familiar remarks are made upon whatever had occurred of interest pertaining to Freedom, during the month just expired.  I always enjoy them much.  The visit of Kossuth, and the bearing it is likely to have upon the cause of Liberty, are the grand themes for discussion at present.  Tuesday evening a little praying circle met in father's study.  For more than a score of years their pastor's study has been their Bethel.  Tuesday, the old year's last day - the rain came "tap, tap, tapping" at the window all the day long, but my fingers
Completed

and my mind were fully occupied with the daily round of household duties, and, in the after part of the day, with sewing and writing a little.  I thought very little of the gloomy out door prospect.  But I could not but grow sadder as the old year's moments grew fewer.  Its sun had risen and gone down for the last time and its pleasures and sorrows had alike departed.  Its opportunities for doing or receiving good forever fled, and its records of good and evil deeds about to be sealed up for eternity.  The rain fell faster as evening came on, and the dying year wept as he gave the parting token, his last golden moment, and spoke his farewell in tears.
But the New Year's sun shone in a cloudless sky.  I went out in the forenoon to call on some sick neighbors and in the afternoon attended "Preparatory Lecture", a treat awaited me when I came home, for the mail brought three letter treasures, your own of December 10, first on the list.  I read it many times till father called me to read to him from a paper just received, the farewell speech of the great Hungarian to three thousand ladies in New-York.  I never read anything more truly beautiful or more truly eloquent.  Thursday evening the Annual Meeting of the Dunbarton Singing Society occupied me till half past ten, an unusually late hour, but after getting things through with the matter of business, we happened to get unusually engaged in singing.
Friday, just as we had said good bye to dinner and
Completed

were ready for a quiet afternoon, we heard the sound of sleigh bells close at the door, and instantly were welcoming two ladies who had come to make a long expected visit.  The hours passed rapidly away, as you know time usually does in pleasant society, and I went by request to pass the evening with a good old maiden lady of about seventy years, who dwells in a small cottage all alone.  I used to pity her solitude, but I have about decided she was made to live alone.  She is always trying to do good, and I never saw her sad.  Her heart seems a world of sympathy for all mankind.  
Two more letters have reached me to day - one from brother George, containing the the New Year's wish for us all, expressed in the finest rhyme he ever penned - at least the finest we have seen.  The other from my roommate of Merrimack Institute, with three and a half pages of verses, written on the morning of January 1.  She has a superior mind and is a fine writer.  So five letters have come in this year - quite a bountiful beginning.  Last year my letters written were 64 and received 60.  I have accounted the books I read also.  The number is 25.  (How glad I should be to number all they contained - But I hope I have obtained from them at least some general ideas, which will be very valuable and enable me better to understand what I may read hereafter.  I have been reading "King Henry eighth" and "King Richard third."  What horrid deeds they do record! Enough to make one's blood
Completed

run cold!  Alas! for poor human nature!  I would not have believed that those bearing the semblence of men could sink so low.  
Now in regard to going to Illinois in the Spring- The greatest objection is the unhealthy climate, and I fear more for the effort of this in your own case than for myself.  You would necessarily be subject to more exposure than I.  True you will be more guarded, and know better how to meet attacks of disease than you could know last season and for this season, might escape the "wretched ague."  But what if it should be otherwise, and your health be permanently injured?  One thing more for my parent's sake, I would be as near as possible to home, although I dearly love Illinois - save New Hampshire - all things conspire to make it the dearest state of all; and my heart tells me that with our friend, I could be happy there.  Notwithstanding the objections, I am willing to go, if you decide it is best to remain.
How glad I should be could you be here next week for we are to have another Pastoral Visit on the afternoon and evening of the14th inst. Most assuredly, you will be remembered then. Brother George cannot be with us, but he wishes to arrange his studies so as to leave, and be at home when you come.  He has scarcely seen you at all, and feels very anxious to have the opportunity.  He has not been home since he left.  The distance is sixty miles, and rather an inconvenient route.
Thursday January 8 - This letter should have been sent two days ago by Tuesday's mail , and I'll tell you why it was not. On the afternoon of Monday, one of our good  farmers, living about two and a half miles distant called and invited me to go home with him, saying he would bring me back when I wished.  I went, but as for getting home til this night, I could not. Winds "blew contrary" quite decidedly.  It stormed incessently until last
Completed

Antoinette Dunbarton, New Hampshire
January 23
Jonesboro, February 16, 1852.  Home January 23, 1852
My dear friend,
I welcomed most heartily, this afternoon yours of December 30, after its three weeks journeying.  It does take somewhat longer for letters to come this winter, but they are the dearer when they do come.  You say you never enjoyed the coming of letters from friends, as much as now.  I am very glad to be able to contribute a "mite" to increase your happiness, now that you are a stranger and alone.
I am most happy to hear so good news of your health and that the climate and weather of the Illinois winter seems so much to your mind, but I hardly know what to reply to your inquiry as to what I would say to your remaining.  As I have before written, I should fear most for your health; and if you feel quite sure of safety in this respect, why then the great objections is removed.  I love Illinois, though the year I spent there was full of anxious care and made me more acquainted with sickness and pain than ever before.  I hardly know why, but so far as regards my own feelings, the
Completed

idea of returning there is rather pleasant than otherwise.  Though I should not feel entirely sure that the grim-visaged Ague would not find me out and make me tremble again.  I believe I am inclined to think, with you, that the climate is not so very bad, if proper care be taken to avoid exposure.  But it is sometimes very difficult to decide what one may undertake with safety.
I think I mentioned in a previous letter that a 'Pastoral Visit" had been appointed.  The day and the morning was beautiful - the sky cloudless, but before ten o'clock, the sun was obscured and shown no more though the day - It was exceedingly cod, the snow drifts very deep and in some places almost impassible, and the evening no less - notwithstanding all these unfavorable circumstances, about fifty persons made their way to our little cottage, and we highly enjoyed the interview.  The weather had been cold, stormy and unpleasant ever since.  We have about three feet of snow on a level and drifts like mountains, while it seems you have had only about half an inch of snow all winter!  Could we send you enough for a sleigh ride, we would gladly.
We could part with it, without the least
Completed

inconvenience.   Had you been here on the first day of January, I could have presented you with a bouquet of real flowers from our garden.  We were having somewhat of a thaw at the time.  The snow was nearly melted away from one of the beds, and out peeped the dear little Heartsease, and the Cypress just as fresh and bright and green as if warming them in the summer's sun.  We gathered some of the blossoms and kept them in water for a long time.
I have been reading to day about France - poor France! It does really seem as if the fearful scenes of the "Reign of Terror" were beginning to be re-enacted.  Their President seems more to resort to the same means to aggrandize himself that were thus employed to pull down royalty.  I saw, in our last paper, that 20,000 persons are imprisoned and many are shot, tortured, and guillotined. How the despots of Europe are struggling against the rising Spirit of Liberty.  It seems to be the opinion of far-seeing minds, that Europe is ere long to be the scene of bloody battles.  Well, I do hope liberty will triumph.  What is your opinion of the duty of this country in regard to aiding Hungary?  Father thinks we should do everything for them we can, without resorting to arms.
It seems we have two brothers attending school this
Completed

Winter.  I presume both are enjoying it finely.  It is such delightful work to study.  George writes regularly every two weeks, though he says he is so busy he can hardly find time.
You speak of my continued anxiety for your health.  I have long since ceased to be anxious about it, for the winter, because you have written how well you are.  But it seems as if it would take as long for you to know it, as it does light to come to us from the fixed stars.  I suppose it takes at least six weeks to write a letter and receive an answer to it.  It makes Illinois seem a great way off.  I suppose it will come earlier in Illinois than in New Hampshire.
With much love and best wishes, I am
Yours most truly
Antoinette
[upside down] Feb. 16
Completed

Dunbarton, Feb. 3, 1852
My dear friend -
This is a magnificent winter evening and I have been thinking of you till it almost seemed as if you were here.  Your kind letter of January 14 came this afternoon.  I was quite happily disappointed in receiving one to day.  I had been trying not to expect a letter, lest it should fail to come!
It seems you have been having more snow and cold weather, and so have we.  We have had an unusual number of storms, and a great amount of snow.  Every Sabbath in this year has been stormy with one exception. I do love to have pleasant Sabbaths; but we must have cloud as well as sunshine.  Last year, I noticed we had a very unusual number of beautiful Sabbath days.  Perhaps the opposite may be true of this year.
I am very happy to know that you have a Presbyterian Minister at Jonesboro' and
Completed

that you are so well pleased with him.  I must seem more like home I think.  I am glad too that he speaks so favorably of Jonesboro' as a location.  I seems to me it must be healthier and pleasanter than the prairies.
You ask what I would think of Illinois as a home.  I suppose before this reaches you, you will have received two letters telling you how I feel about it.  My ideas are still the same, and my heart still replies to you, "Whither thou goest, I will go."
I would like to know a little more definitely how we will be situated, supposing I go back with you in the Spring, but if you leave the very first of next month, I think there will be not time for me to get a reply to this letter, so I leave all the questions for another time.  And besides, I presume your next letters will contain the information I would like.  I have found this frequently the case - you would seem to anticipate what I wished to know and tell me.
I have just been reading of the success of "Liquor Law" in Maine.  I should think you would glory in your state.  This seems to be the guiding Star in Temperance now; and her light is shining all over the Union.  The
Completed

"Granite State" people had another great Temperance Convention at Concord last week, the result of which we hope will be great and good.  It was very fully attended - father said he never was in the midst of such a jam before.  Every nook and corner of the spacious hall in which they met was crowded.  This shows the interest of the people.
I think you must have had a very pleasant interview with your good, kind friends at Mount Hawkins.  I am thinking too, that you have more "mothers" who would like to see you oftener.  But I do not believe they will be disposed to complain much knowing how you have been situated.
I was quite delighted with your account of the winter forests in Illinois, and their bright-winged, musical dwellers.  How I should love to watch them, and hear them sing.  Will we not be happy as they?  And far happier too - for, with grateful hearts, we may together praise "Him from whom all blessings flow."
Here sit dear mother and I, by the bright, warm fire. Mother is knitting and
Completed

singing, while I am making the pen fly.  The moon and stars are peeping in at us, through the window.  Now here comes father to join us.  He thinks it is too late to write longer, so I must be a good girl and stop.  I do not know as there will be time for me to write again.  If I find there will be, after hearing from you again, I will do so.
Father and mother send much love.  So does your own
Antoinette.
Completed

Dunbarton, February 20, 1852
My dear friend,
Now I am just going to write a "wee bit" of a note to you, this time, for I am very much in doubt about there being time for you to receive it, before you leave to come East.
Your good letter came to night; and right glad I was to see it.  But it really makes me feel gloomy that you are obliged to wait so very long for letters, and for an answer to your inquiry about my going to Illinois, I do hope you have before now, received as many as two letters replying to that question.
This is the fourth time you have written with reference to remaining west and no response yet!  I should think
Completed

you would be entirely discouraged.  But I see no help for the matter.  The stormy winds will blow, despite the letters and I really think it is remarkable that not a letter has been lost.
Your last, placed the situation of things, and your prospects for the future, in a more pleasing light than ever; and I am of course not less disposed to think favorably of your plan to remain.  To be sure it seems far away, and we would both, for many reasons, love to be in New England.  But it seems best for you to be where you are, and I acquiesce in your decisions, and have been making preparations accordingly.
Father is calling me to go and look at the Northern Lights, so I must leave writing for a few minutes.  I'll tell you
Completed

about it when I come back.  Well, I have been gazing for half an hour at the mysterious "lights".  I believe I never saw anything so awfully grand.  Now red as blood, now a rich golden hue, and now again a silvery whiteness, they stream over the entire concave glowing, and quivering, and flashing as if the whole were literally inflamed.
I do not wonder at the superstitious fears of the ancients.  It is certainly fearful to view them to night. One could easily imagine the world on fire.
Now I'll tell you of an intellectual light that has recently dawned in our little village.  It is our "Reading Circle."  The young people of the neighborhood meet twice in the week (on Monday and Friday evenings) and spend about two hours in reading historical matter.  Sketches of distinguished characters.  We began with
Completed

doubts and fears, but the plan has succeeded beyond our most sanguine expectations.  New faces greet us at every meeting and all are exceedingly interested.  We have read the  "Private and Public Life of Franklin," Napoleon's expedition to Egypt, the Treason of Arnold, and have commenced the story of Charlotte Corday.
I am glad you have a good horse. If you are as fond of one as father, it will be a very great source of pleasure to have him high spirited, playful and gentle.  Father delights to have a horse which nobody but himself can manage.  I used to ride horseback when in Illinois and enjoyed it highly, but I have hardly been on a horse since.  I rode father's horse for a short distance, twice, last summer.  So you will see I am but a novice in the art.  Nevertheless "she is not yet so old but she may learn."
Well March is almost here, and unless your next letters tell me something new, I suppose I shall not have to write again at present.  Father and mother send much love, and as much as you please from 
Antoinette.
Completed

Antoinette   Dunbarton New Hampshire
February 27, 1852
Jonesboro March 13 1852
Home, February 27, 1852
My dear friend, -
I have been writing all day long, for the town, copying the Report of the Superintending School Committee, of which father is Chairman, but it is completed now and I gladly engage in the more pleasing duty of writing to you.  Yours of February 1 and February 7, reached me last week.  Two letters in one week!  How good it did seem and how I wished it would always be so.  I mailed a little letter last Saturday thinking it might be the last I should write, at present; but yours of the seventh inst. came by the mail of the same day, and
changed the prospect somewhat.  I am very sorry that you are disappointed in carrying out your plans; and hope you will not be long in suspense, it is so unpleasant.  I try to think circumstances will favor your coming to New Hampshire soon.  I knew that I wished to see you before; but not how much till I found there was doubt about your coming this Spring.  If it cannot be, I presume it will prove, as Hannah More's "Patient Joe" said everything did, to be "for the best", and we will take all the comfort
Completed

possible in writing letters.  The great storms must be very nearly over now and they will go quick.  It seems really as if the joyous Spring had come back to us to day.  The snow has begun to leave us and such sunny days as this will soon carry it all away.  But it is very probable we may have more.  March is often a wintry month, though it "wears the gentle name of Spring."  I always love to have it come though, because I know April comes next.
I do not think your letters have been delayed so much as those going westward; at any rate you have been so kind in writing punctually, and there has been so little delay, that I have been spared the trouble almost entirely of waiting vainly for an expected letter; and I can hardly believe that the winter I was dreading so much for this very reason, is juts gone.
You last letters both came in little less than two weeks.  You have had more trouble from this source, but I hope it is over now.  Mother thinks Engineers on the "Central" Rail Roads, have a fine opportunity to learn patience.  Well, I suppose it is all right that we have clouds as well as sunshine; and very dark clouds are sometimes beautifully tinged with sunshine so that we can't help thinking how bright the other
Completed

side must be.  Now am I not a good comforter?  And I must run away and get supper now.
Supper is done, and father has gone away to the study, and mother and Jenny are sewing by the table.  Last evening (Thursday) we had a meeting of the Reading Circle.  Friday is the regular evening for us, but we changed this week to accommodate the Whig Party of the town, who rally their forces to night in anticipation of the coming town meeting.
We read last evening a sketch of Irving and of Bryant, with some specimens of their composition.  The number continues to increase, and all seem as much interested as ever, in the selections.
I do not know but I mentioned in my last the increased interest of our weekly religious meetings.  They are not very fully attended, but those who are present, manifest much more feeling than usual, and seem determined to labor individually for the salvation of souls.  They seem to feel that they have a work to do.
It seems you were once almost a Methodist.  Please tell me, when you have time, when it was, and where, and what prevented you from fully embracing their sentiments.  There really seems to be much to admire in them, and
Completed

some things which it would be very desirable for all denominations to imitate.  I read yesterday, some remarks of one of our New Hampshire clergymen, in reference to the religion of the inhabitants of Wellfleet, on Cape Cod.  He says "they have a union of Methodist real and Orthodox faith, that tells powerfully, especially in prayer meetings.  The difficulty seems to be not in carrying on these meetings but bringing them to a close."  Such meetings must be beneficial.  I never attended a Quarterly Meeting.  Were you able to attend the one you spoke of at Jonesboro'?  My school mate, Miss Peavey, of whom I have spoken to you, I believe, is a Methodist.  She united with that church about two years ago.
I have not quite given up the idea that I may see you in a week or two.  I have been thinking all the while I have been writing, that perhaps you would come to night, and I should not need to send this.  I do not know but I shall feel sad a little, if I cannot see you till August - But I do not think I will "borrow any trouble" about it.
Do not fear you will write too often.  I should like to see a letter every day, if it were best.
Father and mother send love.
Yours most truly,
Antoinette
[upside down]D. Feb. 27  }52

                     J. Mar. 13
Completed

Antoinette    Dunbarton New Hampshire
March 16, 1852
Jonesboro, Illinois April 1, 1852
Dunbarton, March 13, 1852
My dear friend, -
Saturday evening has come again and as usual finds me enjoying a quiet season with my mother.  We have been reading and taking some time, but now we are very still indeed.  Mother is diligently studying the best of books, while I write.  She is preparing her passages for to-morrow morning.  We all commit a scripture selection to recite at the breakfast table.
I have been taking a long walk this afternoon to call on Mrs. French, the widow of one of the Siam Missionaries. Enjoyed the interview and the walk very much indeed. The snow is rapidly going away, and the pleasant voices of the Spring are all around us.  It seems so delightful to see dear little birds flying about, and to listen to the brooks humming along as if to redress the lost time.  I think the fields and the trees must be looking finely in Illinois, by this time.  I remember perfectly the lively green of the
Completed

wheat fields, and a ride I took one day to view one of unusual extent, situated about three miles from my prairie home.  I remember the ride, because I was perched, with the lady of the house where I boarded, on top of an enormous load of wood, piled so high that it was quite a feat to get on or off without a ladder.  I rode in various ways in those days, but "variety is the spice of life," and I found it so, sometimes.  I went to Chicago (32 miles) in company with a sister teacher, on a load of wheat, packed in bags.  We had each a bag for a seat, one to our backs and one for a footstool, and found it mighty comfortable.  We jogged along so slowly that is was very convenient to follow the Dutch woman's fashion and knit the whole way.  A right profitable mode of traveling, we thought it.
If I am home with Spring and Summer as it seems probably now I may be, I intend to try horseback riding again, though it is so long since I have attempted that it will be almost like learning anew.  And besides father's horse is not a very good one for me.
It seems hard to give up the idea of seeing you this Spring.  Summer seems a very great many days off.  But if time files as usual,
Completed

it will very soon come, after all; and I should be an ungrateful child truly to be unhappy here - with the best of parents.  I am inclined to think if you cannot come, and I learn the decision in season, I may enter the school room again, as I have an opportunity in town and may be near home.
Your letter gave as much information about how we may be situated, as I expected you could give now.  I supposed it would be advisable to board at first.  But I am glad we agree in preferring our own home, in our own way.  I think however, that at present, it must be a home "on the wing".  Maybe you will not always be an Engineer, and perhaps we can "settle down,"  in some snug little cottage with fruit trees and knots of flowers and twining vines.  There! How I am talking!  I'll stop here.
(Monday morn, Mary 14)   I should have finished and sent this last Saturday, but thinking I might have news from you, concluded to wait one mail longer.
Last Sabbath was our communion season and the exercises seemed unusually solemn and interesting.  Mr. Bird, a son of the former
Completed

missionary to Syria, and himself an appointed missionary to the same region, spent the day with us and preached.  His heart seemed over-flowing with love to God, and the souls of men, and it seemed as though all must be made better by listening to him.  He is quite young, but seemed perfectly at home as a preacher, and cannot fail to be useful with the warmth of religious feeling and depths of piety so manifest.
He spoke of the amount of happiness of which Christians deprive themselves here and of glory hereafter by not living near to God, and what a fearful thing it is to go to heaven alone bearing no sheaves, when Good has made it our duty, and our privilege to labor to turn many to righteousness and promise His unfailing aid.  The close of his sermon was exceedingly  impressive - representing the entrance of such a Christian to heaven - saved "so as by fire."
You ask what New Hampshire is doing for Temperance.  There have been two very fully attended conventions at Concord, and since the last, Temperance meetings have been held all over the state and more lectures delivered than two years before.  This shows that the people are fully awake on the subject.  Of course we hope it will not stop with  mere excitement and we do not think it can.  Maine should not to be alone in so noble a work.
My friend Miss Peavey was here lst week a few days, and we had a fine visit together. She wished you would come while she was here.  She every anxious indeed to see you.  She does not expect to be married now, before summer or perhaps Autumn.
I hope to hear from you very soon.  I cannot help thinking of the horrid ague occasionally now Spring has come again.  But I think you will certainly let me know if you are not well.
With best love, and best wishes, I am
Yours ever
Antoinette.
Completed

Dunbarton, March 27, 1852
My dear friend, -
Father is gone to Concord this afternoon, so I am occupying his study.  I am sitting in his chair and writing on his desk, so if there should be any good in this you can readily account for it.
I do not feel quite so joyous as usual today.  It seems a very long while since I have heard from you.  The last date was February 22, and it is more than three weeks since it came.  I presume a letter has been miscarried, or lost somewhere on the way.  Really, I believe I never knew the days seem so long in life.  Never longed to hear from you so much before, or to see you.  I makes me think how far away you are.
Since I wrote last, we have almost had another winter.  At any rate we have had some very cold days, and two or three snows storms.  Wednesday morning last, the new snow was about a foot in depth, and it is so cold that it diminishes very little.  But I do hope we can have had the last
Completed

snow, for this has been a long and cold winter.  I heard it remarked yesterday, that there have been 32 snow storms since October. That seems to be a sufficient number.
Last evening the "Reading Circle" met.  We have not yet finished "Napoleon".  We are reading now the Syrian Expedition.  When we commenced the meetings of the circle, everybody expected it would be short lived.  Just as every undertaking has almost invariably proved to be here but, strange to say, we have not failed a full attendance, two evenings in every week during the whole time, and there seems an unabated interest.
I have been reading at home, "The Works of Hannah More", and also Longfellow's Poems and now father has purchased for us "Uncle Tom's Cabin" by H. B. Stowe.  It will not take us long to complete this, for it is so interesting that when once commenced, it will be hard to leave it.  I am now reading a very valuable work, which I presume you may have seen, illustrating Christian doctrine, and the difference between true and false religion, and answering the cavillers objections.  It is "Pilgrims Progress
Completed

in the Nineteenth Century." by W. R. Weeks.  I hope we can get it into our S.S. Library so that it may be extensively read in the town.  I know not what would, or could be better.  It makes Christian duty very plain and clothes with attraction, themes in themselves dry and abstruse.
I do not believe I can write a very long letter this day, for there are two workmen in the other room, a mason and a carpenter, fixing the chimney, fire board, etc. preparatory to the installation of a new stone.  They talk so fast and so loud, and require so much attention, that I can hardly think or write at all.
It is so late now that I begin to think it nearly certain that you cannot come East before the summer.  Of course, I feel very anxious to know what the decision is. Sometimes I think it may be that no letter comes, because you are on the homeward way.  I like this thought very well.  A "living epistle" would be truly welcome.
Father and mother send much love to you.  Hoping to hear from you very soon, I am with my best love, truly yours.
Antoinette
Completed

What suppose you it meaneth?  I shall be troubled if I do not hear soon.  Nothing from Anna since you left.  Samuel is gone to Oldtown today about lumber.  It rains quite fast and steadily, seems chilly and damp.  Mrs. McLaughlin is here washing.  Lucy has no girl yet and Mallie says she doesn't want any till we are back from Milo. Mallie makes bread, pies and cake.  She says I must tell you that I am good all, but carrying baby upstairs. Please to believe I have vomit but twice since you left and then when I got tired and went to bed before Samuel came home and Sabra had gone beforehand. I expect Mallie is good without any exception.  I see nothing to the contrary.
I am glad you went to the Crystal Palace even for a short time.  Wish you had had your cloak to befriend you those cold nights.  Longfellow is an excellent selection
Completed

for Mr. Rowley.  Bryant would have been good also.  I am perfectly satisfied about it, though I had not thought to get a book, quite so expensive.  If your mother thinks of any book she would like for any of the children, we will send for it.  I had procured those I mentioned before your letter came.  Mayo has not tumbled out of bed yet, and I do not believe we will let him.
I like the pen you got very much indeed.  Percie is not very well - bad cold yet.  Had a touch of croup since you left.  I suppose you are in Illinois before this.  Remember me to the old friends there.  Mrs. Keyes, the people of Mt. Hawkins, Mr. Smith, etc.  I will send you commercial sheets when I get home, so do not make wry faces at this if you can refrain therefrom.  Lucy says be doubly careful of your health with no wife to take care for you or of you - So do, will you not my Isaac?  Mayo kisses papa in the case, all these days. So does your own,
Nettie.
Completed

Home, April 10, 1852
Saturday evening, with all its quiet, is here again.  I have been thinking a long while and now will write a little. When I wrote last, I was waiting to hear from you, and feared a letter might have been lost, but in process of time, it has come and was truly welcome.  
It seems you were having, in March, the weather of New England May.  I should like to view the prospect from your window; indeed I should enjoy viewing anything that seems spring-like.  We are almost tired of waiting for the snow to be gone.  Winter still holds undisputed sway, and the warm winds linger in the sunny south.  Last Monday, father stood upon a snow bank nearly six feet high and measured a giant icicle pendant from the eaves of the house.  It was thirty one inches long, and five and one half inches round at the largest end. Another, eighteen inches long, lay on the bank.  This was the afternoon, too, after it had been thawing some all day.  The next day we had a severe snow storm.
I must tell you about some apples Jenny saved for you.  They were beautiful great ones and were waiting down cellar for you to come.  In excellent health they were all winter long, blushing every time I looked upon them. And seeming in a fever of expectation till first of March passed.  Then, not being so stouthearted as I, they could endure no longer, but began visibly to decline and you may guess their fate - poor things!
Completed

I was exceedingly interested in what you relate of your experience regarding Methodism, and the Methodists.  It was in 1841, the same year you were at Brownville, that I united with the people of God, and hope I gave my heart to Christ.
That was before you went to Brunswick, was it not?  By the way, was not Boston your native place?  We have been talking about it and could not quite decide.  Father said he believed your father had a residence, and a farm in the country, at the same time he was employed in Boston.  But he could not recollect where.  You will think we have all rather treacherous memories, and so we have.
Last Thursday was our State Fast. I suppose no such day is observed in Illinois.  We had a meeting all day, and sermon in the afternoon.  Father's text was Matthew 16:3.  "Can ye not discern the signs of the times"?  The passage was applied to the signs of the times relating to the present day, more especially as they are presented in the political world.  He spoke at length, of the European revolutions, and the present state of affairs in that quarter of the globe; and the contest which seems to be in
Completed

prospect between "absolutism and republicanism".  I suppose it will be admissible for me to say to you, that I thought it an exceeding interesting discourse.  It made me feel as if we were indeed living "in a grand and awful time", "in an age on ages telling".
We have finished "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and it makes slavery seem worse than ever.  If there is anything in the wide world that I hate with perfect hatred, it is the very name of Slavery.  I wish I could do something to help "tread it out". I hope Miss  Stowe's book will travel though the length and breadth of the land, winning hearts and hands at every step.
I have been reading too, about the persecutions among the Protestants of Madagascar.  Isn't it horrible?  I could not but think, if professed Christians here were called to endure such fiery trials, how many would prove firm and faithful to the end?  I do not know, but it seems to me sometimes, that a very small proportion of Christ's professed followers have that happy trusting confidence in God, that ardent, whole-souled love to Him, which make the cheerful, self denying, and enduring Christian;  few who like Peter, can speak to the Searcher of
Completed

hearts and say, Lord, thou knowest all things, thou knowest that I love thee.  And yet such a state of mind certainly seems desirable.  What constant need there is of watchfulness and prayer, and heart-searching.  It seems no little thing to be a Christian.
Monday morn.)  The patient robins are singing merrily this morning, despite the snow.  Father has gone to visit some sick people and as usual, when I get an opportunity, I have usurped his writing desk, and its appurtenances in his absence.  I must get this letter, and another one, ready for the next mail.  So I do not write very slowly, as you must perceive.  I think Father is going tomorrow morning (unless something unfortunate prevents) to attend an "Association" meeting at Merrimack.  I think I shall go with him, as far as Mr. W. Raymond's and stop there till his return.
George is tremendous glad that you cannot come East till summer.  What a boy!  I suppose he thinks he may see you now.  His vacation begins the last week in July and continues through the month of August.
Glancing at my letter, I see it travels about all over the world.  I hope you will excuse such rambling.  You must know there cannot be much in little Dunbarton to write about.  But I must stop now.  
Father and mother send much love.
Accept very much from,
Yours ever truly
Antoinette
Antoinette, March 12 Dunbarton
Jonesboro, March 24 1852
Completed

Dunbarton April 25, 1852 

My dear friend,

        Some time ago, as much as two hours, I should think, I sat down with pen, ink and paper in readiness, with the laudable intent to write a letter for you. I was a little wearied, and felt not exactly in a writing mood,- it seemed to be I had not the most forlorn remnant of an idea so I took up a book to read a few moments and the time has flown just as it always does when one is reading something interesting. I have been reading a description of Mammouth Cave, written by Mr. Charles Tenney, once my teacher, at Gilmanton Academy. He spent some months, last Autumn, in journeying South and West. The sense of the beautiful and the sublime is really oppressive when reading a highly wrought description of the marvels of that Subterranean world. I was obliged to sit still for a time after finishing the narrative, till I could feel quite sure that I was "in the body", and surrounded by the plain, wooden walls of my own home, instead of being in the fairy regions of that wondrous cavern

[left-hand side and top] I shall of course be anxious to learn of the decision about your going to the North of the state. Father seems to think that for himself he should like the north of Illinois best = He thinks it would be more healthy and that the society - better - and there he says it would be somewhat nearer to New England. It is time I stopped writing. I was just thinking you might possibly be making preparations for a journey East, about this time, because your last letter said you might be able to get away a month. But I do not make airy calculations for I fear it was was not very likely you can come till Summer. A welcome is ready and waiting for you whenever you can come, be assured. Ever truly yours, Antoinette Much love from father and mother.
Completed

walking by its river banks, traversing its halls, and chambers, its galleries and its grottoes sparkling with chrystals; while its arches echo back the "ohs and ahs of wonder", like the voices of invisible spirits - but enough of this - I must tell you how glad I was to see your letter. I came by our last mail - indeed we have had but one mail this week, because of the great freshet, - and it is very doubtful about our getting another for some days yet. The cars all about us are stopped - none between Concord and Boston. None on the N.H. Central  Road. In one place, on the last mentioned, about half a mile out of Goffstown Village where a bend in the river encircles an elevation of land about 40 or 50 feet high, the bank was undermined by the river, and swept away and all. People who have lived there for thirty years, never saw the river so high before. Last week, on the 13 and 15 inst., we had very great snow storms, and a greater weight of snow fell than at any one time during the whole winter. For five days if this week we have had rain almost incessently, and this great body of snow is almost entirely gone except
[upside down bottom of page] Antoinette Dunbarton Apr. 27
Completed

where there were enormous drifts.

    You speak of your solitary Sabbath Afternoons -really you must feel rather alone sometimes, I should think. But my heart is thankful that one dares to be singular among that Sabbath-visiting community. What a lamentable state of things when clergymen and church alike with non-professors make a gala day of the Sabbath. I am glad you have the privilege of being alone- for I used to think it would be an unspeakable one when boarding in houses where it was next to impossible to be by myself - house with only one room and a loft. It is unpleasant to be obliged to stay in the midst of a gay company, on the Sabbath, who spend their time in laughing and talking of every subject, save that which should be the theme.
     Last evening was the closing meeting of the "Reading Circle", and a very interesting time we had. I do not know but I wrote you that father, and our physician, (who had a very thorough knowledge of history,) have attended many of the meetings, and added much to their interest by discussing the various characters which were brought to view, in the course of the reading. They were both present last evening, and, as we were just closing the "Life of Alfred the Great," they helped us to trace comparisons, and differences
Completed

between him and Napoleon.

    All seemed to regret that it as the last evening, - but since the evenings are so short, it seemed advisible to stop. They will probably be returned when  the long evenings come again.
     I am glad your brother is so much better. What a wonder that he was not even more seriously injured or even killed! I had not heard about the accident before.
    I have been out, this afternoon, to spend a few hours with the wife of our physician. You would have been interested and perhaps pleased to have heard a part of the conversation at least, - the questions and replies regarding the prospective of our lives - that which is as yet the unknown future.
     The parsonage seems to be a sort of depository or receptacle of all the joys and sorrows of the parish. To the pastor's study they come and open a whole budget of greivances to find redress; or unfold their takes of whatever distresses or pleases them, expecting advice or sympathy as the case may demand, and seeming, in their turn, to deem all that pertains to the welfare of their pastor and his family, as their common property. This manifestation of  interest in our well being it is pleasant to perceive, though sometimes we feel as if it would be quite as comfortable not to be quite so public characters. The good matrons here, some of the gray-headed ones too, seem to feel about as much interest in my affairs and prospects as if I were their child;  and I feel somewhat of the same confidence in them that I do in my own dear parents. I should be so glad if you knew some of these dear, good friends, for I should love to write often about them if you did. They are not the rich and the great, but "the quaint and quiet ones," plain and honest hearted. So you may imagine many a question is bestowed, for which I am grateful, and, of which we may perhaps sometime reap the benefit. There is one in Milan, Morgan County, Ohio, an early and tried friend of mother's who is very anxious to see you. Her letters almost uniformly contain a word of counsel for me.
Completed

Antoinette Dunbarton
                                                                                                                                                                                                      May 8 52
                                                                                                                         Dunbarton, May 8, 1852

My dear friend,

               I feel so very stupid to night, that if your good letter of April 25 had not just been recieved and read, I do not believe I could have written a word. I feel quite perceptably brighter since reading it.
            First I must disclose to you what I have been doing the past week. After recieving yours of March 14, I relinquished entirely the idea of seeing you before July or August; and as mother and Jenny seemed not to require my assistance at home, and I did not like the idea of being useless, or unemployed, and had an application to take a small school near home, I decided to do so, and commenced operations last Monday.
    Had I received yours of Apr. 4, in which you state that you may come East very soon, I should not of course have engaged the school; but it is a small one, and I can leave it with very little trouble. It closes the last week in June at any rate - only eight weeks long. Now I hope this will

[left-hand side and top]  I hope you will excuse this careless letter, for I have written hurriedly. You think I must agree that you write often. Your letters are worth a great deal to me and never come too often. Do not fear writing too many if you have time to spend so. Most truly yours, Antoinette.  I shall look for you a little this week and shall be most happy if you come.
Completed

not trouble you. I engaged the school because I did not feel as if I ought to consult my own pleasures so much and to stay at home, unless mother needed me - doing nothing for my own support. I enjoy teaching very much indeed, and hope to be of some use to my pupils. I feel as much enthusiasm now, as I ever did in commencing school, and have enjoyed this week much. The children are unusually forward for those so young - the school room is, I think on the whole, the most comfortable and convenient one in town. I was thinking to day, I did wish you could just step in and see us - almost in the woods, as we are. We are trying our best to make the wilderness bud  and blossom as the rose.

    I think I never saw in one week, so great a change in the whole face of Nature as during the week just past. Two weeks ago there was a good deal of snow on the ground, and the beginning of this week was so cold as to freeze quite hard, but since Wednesday the heat has been quite oppressive, and the change wrought seems perfectly bewildering.  The fields begin to look green - the trees are covered with great buds, and the cowslip
Completed

the Arbutus, and Garden Violet, have sprung up as if by magic - all in full bloom - seeming more enchantingly beautiful than ever, after the long winter we have had.

    How interesting it must be to have those European refugees in your company. I am glad you told me about them. If you come East soon, will you not be quite likely to encounter Kossuth somewhere on the way? I hope you will. It will be quite an event to me to see someone who has seen Kossuth.
    I rejoice that the course of Temperance seems advancing in Jonesboro. May rich blessings attend your efforts, and those of others, to aid the cause.
   So your beautiful horse is dead. We all sympathize - and we know how - for, a short time since, father lost a beautiful and valuable horse, which we all prized and loved. So we learned "how dear a thing without a soul can be." He had a cough, and pined away as if in consumption. He really seemed to have more affection and heart, than some human beings. His head was laid on father's shoulder whenever he could manage to get it there. Father paid $115 for him, when a colt, and he had always been a pet with us all.
Completed

Father feels miserably tonight. He took cold some days since, and has had a bad cough. He thinks the prospect with regard to his preaching on the morrow is rather dubious; and beside the two sermons in prospect for the Sabbath, two funerals are to be attended on Sunday. There have occurred two deaths in town to day - quite an unusual event. One was a lady of more than 70 years, - a member of the church here, and always a consistant Christian. She had been a long time sick. The other was a young lady just 20 years old - a beautiful girl sick 12 weeks. A few weeks ago, she expressed hope in Christ: An interesting and promising young man, who bride she was to have been, called to day to talk with father. He had also indulged hope within a short time - some three months. But the clock has just struck twelve times, and I must not write longer. Good night.

   Here comes Monday morning. Washing and breakfast are done and when this letter is finished I must hie away  to meet my little band of scholars. Since Saturday night the buds on the trees have become little leaves and a thunder shower last night made the grass look green.
  Father succeeded in speaking - miraculously, yesterday - said he had not spoken easier for six weeks. So we are blessed. I shall wait anxiously the result of your interview with Col. Mason, and to know what you decide to do this summer. I do not exactly fancy the idea of your being in the midst of such oceans of prairie as you wrote about. But if it seems best for you, I shall be content.
Completed

Home, May 28. 1852

My dear friend,-

                         This is a beautiful Sabbath afternoon so calm and still that it seems as if all Nature were keeping the day "holy unto the Lord." We have had quite a full meeting - I have been all day. This forenoon father presented the claims of the Home Missionary Society - speaking particularly of our duty with regard to the great West. He brought to view the great extent of our country, comparing its territory, lakes, rivers etc. with the Eastern World, - its vast resources, its rapid increase from emigration. His text was "Occupy till I come." Luke 19; 13. O what a charge was that which Christ committed to his followers - and how little has been done towards converting the world.
  I am glad a Sabbath School has been commenced at Jonesboro. Doubtless it will be the means of accomplishing great good. I shall think of you and your Bible Class as often as Sabbath morning cones. Mother was greatly interested in the descriptive part of your last letter, but she says nothing pleased her so much as to know you were engaged in instructing a class of young men in Bible truth. She hopes your efforts may be greatly blessed.
    Our Sabbath School was reorganized last Sabbath. For a year past I have been a scholar, and have
Completed

enjoyed it much, very much, but I have now taken charge of a class of misses, two in number. It is an interesting class, the very one of all others which I should have selected, had I chosen for myself.

May 24} I found your good letter of May 9 - waiting for me on my return from school Saturday after noon, and welcomed it most gladly. You speak of irregularity in the mails. I hope it will not long continue. I mailed a letter Apr. 27, and another May 11, one or both of which you may have received before now. It seems you have been having great storms as well as we. But we are having magnificent days now, and delightful scenery I had thought till your letter came; but - I can tell no tale which will at all compare with yours, though I have felt that my measure of happiness was well night full, when gazing upon the green lawns, glittering like emerald, and the deepening foliage, and distant blue mountains. O these mountains! "A midst them is my home."  I shall always love them. I should delight to see the trees you describe. How perfectly splendid that forest scenery must be, and how glad I am that you are well, and can enjoy it, as I know you must. And then those ancient ruins. It must be interesting to examine them, and revert to their probably origin and design. You will be likely to find interesting relics quite often, I suppose.
  I am really delighted with your descriptions of
Completed

scenery. I read them over and over again, and set my imagination at work to picture them into visible forms.

  Emilie Peavey, the dear friend of my school days, of whom I have written to you, was married last Wednesday morning, at her home in Landaff, and started away just after dinner, on a three weeks visiting tour, among their mutual friends. They were here Friday evening, but I did not see them, being away at School - wasn'nt it almost too bad? I though it was. But they left - love, c? and cake for me, and Emilie a kiss, and a dear little flower. So I comforted myself over the relics, and wished you were here to enjoy them with me.
   They are going back by way of the beautiful lake Winnipeseque Winnipesaukee, and the Franconia mountains. 
   I should love to writ more, but am obliged to go away to school very early this morning, and must deny myself the pleasure this time. With my best love, truly, A.B.P. (Archbishop.)
Completed

Home, June 25, 1852.

My dearest friend,

   I must say dearest this time, for I am so full of sympathy that I cannot help it. What a doleful time you have had. I have just finished my school and come home - just - this moment entered the house, - but I thought I must sit down the very first thing, and begin to write a letter of condolence & of congratulation too, that you are better, and able to advance. Father has been down to attend examination. He brought me your letter, and I have been reading it on the way home. I am gad you "patience and philosophy" proved so effectual in sustaining you; they are commodities of such a character as will not be
Completed

diminished by exercise, but rather strengthened and enriched. I trust yours have been enriched by this trial at least - "twenty dollars" worth, so that you are made no poorer thereby.

  Perhaps you are in Zanesville about this time. We formerly had relatives there, and have some now, accross the river from there, at Putnam. You thought you would be at Westfield about July 1. Then I shall be looking for you here by the 3rd shall I not? How pleasant it will be for you and your sister to journey East in company - it is quite fortunate that her vacation happens just now. I hope you will persuade your sister to come here with you.  Father and mother too are anxious to have her come. We should all be most happy to see her, and
Completed

shall expect her. I suppose brother George will be home from Meriden just about that time. He finds it somewhat hard to study during the warm weather, and is coming a little sooner than he expected, when at home last. He seems to imagine he can study considerable at home. We are all rejoicing that he is coming so soon - he has not been home since the first of March, and then only one week.

   I feel rather releived to think my school is really through, though I have enjoyed it very much indeed -  a very comfortable feeling of freedom comes over me to night.
  I suppose I shall have a full and particular account of your travels when you come, and I must be patient till then. I will not write longer for I feel somewhat doubtful about you ever receiving this. How kind you have
Completed

been to write so often on your way? If you do not come next week, I suppose I may hear from you again, - but we shall confidently expect you

                                             Truly as ever
                                                         Antoinette.

Antoinette Dunbarton
June 25 1852
Dunbarton
Completed

Home, June 26, 1852.

My dear friend

      My school closed yesterday, and after I came home last night, I sat down and wrote a reply to yours of the 18 inst. so that I might send it to Concord, to be mailed early this morning, and thus be on the way to you sooner than if mailed here. We sent another for George with it - and both were lost in the street. So we are disappointed, and I fear this cannot now reach Westfield in season for you - but perhaps it may. Your letter came by Thursday's mail {24} telling me about your being sick etc. What a doleful time you have had!
Completed

My heart has been overflowing with sympathy for you. I am very happy that you are better and able to advance. You must have felt solitary - and sadly enough - among strangers, in such a place, and suffering so much. But I am full of rejoicing that it proved no worse, and that you are really well again, or at least, getting well. 

   I am glad the draft made upon your "patience and philosophy" proved so effectual in sustaining you. I suppose they are commodities of such a character as not to be diminished by exercise, but rather strengthened and increased, - enriched I presume, in your case, at least to the value of "twenty dollars," so that you are really no loser, by the trial.
Completed

You are perhaps at Zaneville about this time. We formerly had relatives there, and have now accross the river from there, at Putnam. You thought you would be at Westfield by July 1st. Shall we not be looking for you by the 3d?  You and your sister will enjoy the journey together very much. How fortunate that her vacation happens just now. I hope she will come here with you. Will you not persuade her to do so? I should dearly love to see her, and father & mother are very anxious that she should come. May we not expect her with you, by the last of next week?   George will probably be at home about that time.
Completed

He is coming somewhat sooner than he expected, when last at home - because he finds it rather hard to study in the warm days. He is going to bring home his books. He seems to imagine he can study considerable at home. We are all very glad to have him come so soon - he has not been home since March, and then, but for one little week.

   It seems strange to have no school to think of, or dream about. I feel quite releived that it is through - though I have enjoyed it very much indeed, and felt sorry to part from the bright eyes, happy faces and merry voices of the dear children. No one of them was more than thirteen years old - but all were fine scholars for those so young. I think I never found better ones.
     You have been very kind to write so often on your way. If you cannot come next week, I suppose I may hear from you again; but we shall confidently expect you by Saturday. I suppose I shall have a full account of your travels when you come - so I must be very patient till then. I will not write longer to night.
                                                              Truly as ever, yours,
{Saturday Eve.}                                                       Antoinette
Completed

Bangor June 13  54
De Quoin July 1  54

                                                                                                               Tuesday night June 13, 1854.
                                                                                                                 {Bangor}

My dearest Isaac,

                                  Your letter written at Virginia Hotel, St. Louise, June 4 - reached here yesterday having been just one week on the way -came with speed did it not? Don't I wish they would all come so. O how good it is to see your hand writing when letters come. I am very glad you felt so finely - so little fatigued on reaching St. Louis.
