I do not wonder you fell asleep on the sabbath - after your night journeyings. By this time you are absorbed again in R.R. matters. I hope to know soon where your stopping place is to be  - office etc.  Our long anticipated journey East all past - can it be? And you so far away from me & our little Mayo baby as can be. Don't get too much absorbed. Mr. Shepherd said in his remarks last sabbath - "God says, ' let every thing that hath breath praise the Lord.' Mammon says, 'Let everything that hath muscle, dig.'" Said people gave themselves no time comfortably to sleep or healthfully to eat. It was a plain, pointed sermon to business men a most Excellent one. Lucy and I went together in afternoon. Mr. Post was in Boston when you were in St. Louis was he not? -- Here has been a
Completed

pause. I had to help about getting baby to sleep, for some reason he cried, and was some time getting quiet. He has been full to overflowing today of fun and roguery. He shakes hands vigorously with any of us - stands up all alone in the middle of the floor, walks quite accross the entry with one hand holding to my dress- and it seems to me grows heavy constantly. How you would love to watch him. O dear - but I'll not say a word about the "long time" I'll try to keep you informed of all 'Corry's wonderful deeds, and will both keep as well and happy as possible. The little fellow is just asleep now - he is a darling baby. Percie is well now, and we are going to Milo, Lucy and I, with the babies & Sabra, tomorrow morning nothing preventing. Samuel is joining also - we have been waiting some time for him to go. He has been to Frankfort today. Sabra does well. Mr. Shepherd has been in this evening to call. What a bashful man he is - it was so hard for him to say anything. Neither Samuel or Eliab were here to see him. He is a good man, and I love to hear him preach. Lucy and Maria made a pair of shirts for him, and he thanked them tonight for the same. I have not heard one word from Dunbarton yet. What can it mean. Mayhaps father & mother have gone a journey. Anna writes that she will start about 26 June get here about sixth July - spend "the Fourth" in
Completed

Boston. Lucy thinks I had better stop for her, and I should dearly love to; but I fear father and mother will feel it. I can tell better what to do after hearing from them. Hattie has got nicely over the measles and Lissie has them now, but it recovering.

 I like Mallie. I think Lucy is ever so much like my Isaac. She reminds me of you many times - Eliab too I should imagine to be your own brother. I am getting more acquainted with the latter. I am happy with our dear friends here. It is so pleasant to feel that I am cared for by those so dear to you - so very pleasant to love them and think the love returned. Eliab keeps asking me which baby I love best, & wh. I think handsomest. I got Rolls & work & play, bound in one {.62c} to carry Charlie. We all read "Parish Side" and have exchanged it for "Father Brighthopes" which is a very good little volume. Lucy wants Albina to have it immediately. We finished it today. I must stop and go to bed, I suppose - all the rest have gone. I miss your dearest all the time, but I think, with you, it is better not to fret. We are all in a kind Father's hands, who is able to keep us and grant us all we need and permit us again in due time to meet. Please don't hurry and work too hard will you?
                                                           Most truly your own
                                                                                     Nettie B.
Completed

Bangor June 2 54
Du Coign July 6 54

                                                                                                                                                                  Bangor,- Tuesday, June 20, 1854

Dearest Isaac,-
It is past team time - Samuel & Eliab have both run been here to eat - and Samuel had gone back but because it is a rainy night and not much doing at the store Eliab stays to spend an evening with his Mallie, - and here sit they, close by the secretary where I am writing Eliab is reading the "Lamplighters" and putting an arm about Mallie while she is at work - I have just undressed 'Corry' and Sabra is getting him to sleep - He has been stretching him on the floor, just as he used to do when he wanted to rest He and Percie both have felt badly all day tired out with the ride from Milo yesterday and having troublesome times with mosquito bites there obtained - O how thick the creatures were - I never saw so many before - Mother says she makes a regular business of destroying them. Samuel amused us greatly with his zeal to kill them - He made a big smoke daily, and at night with a lighted candle pursued them from room to room and let the flames devour them - after all they did trouble us some at night and early in the morning.
Completed

Samuel has been to Oldtown today. It has been very warm yesterday and today - but is cooler tonight since the rain. Lucy is getting Percie to sleep and E. & Maria have gone to their room & Sabra has taken sleeping little Mayo up to bed, so here I sit alone now. O how I should love to see you tonight. Lucy engaged a new girl while we were gone to Milo - Mary Hamlet - I think from Brownville. The stage brought her today. Lucy heard afterwards that she was 'light-fingered,' and she feels as if she should not keep her long. Still she is bright & active & may improve and be a good girl. Eliab is as good as can be about most things but he will be naughty some. I told him I should tell you he asked me naughty questions! Such as this How do you like Isaac? Then he'll get close up to Mallie and kiss her and ask me if you do so, and if I like to have you - and he makes my cheeks burn about every day. What would you do to him! - 'Dear Isaac, I am glad you and I have so good brothers and sisters. I do love them all, and am generally enjoying this visit. Caty has this day gone home. Lucy thought she could get along with the new girl better without her. Sabra has been not very well to day, but seems better to night. I think she will be quite well
Completed

tomorrow. I think I'll not write anymore till morning, then I'll give you a wee bit journal of the week past.
{Journal} Wednesday June 14 - Went to Milo. Samuel got a large carriage and Lucy & himself & baby & self & baby rode therein. Sabra went in the stage & walked from the corner with a note of introduction, and told the people we were coming. We stopped to dinner at Bradford.  What a miserable hotel! Lucy says it grows worse & worse every time she stops there. Had pleasant ride, not very warm, got there about five, started at nine in morning. All glad to see us. I do not see as mother grows old. Albina looks nicely. Charlie & Josie a few inches higher up. What a decided character little Mary is. Mother says when she takes Mayo and looks in his face- I can hardly believe it is Isaac's baby.

  Thursday June 15 . Went to Brownville - delightful ride by Pleasant River- called at Mr. Sewall's a few moments- reached Brownville about noon- found all well. Mayo was full of frolic as could be. Mr. Rider seemed to enjoy playing with him and laughing at him very much. He played so long after undressing that he felt cold after it I expect for he cried very hard a little while. He took four or five steps all alone today. Mother said he would soon go alone, and that she had no expectations of seeing, physically, in little Mayo so strong and healthy a child. She thought he would be puny.
  Friday June 16. went back to Milo in the P.M. Almeda wanted us to stay till strawberry time, but Lucy said that
Completed

all our visit was at Milo before and she thought we had better go back to Bangor with her & Samuel - you know when before I spent most of my time at the dentist's. We called on Col. Lee's on way back. He was sorry not to have seen you - said he could have thought you might have come just to the door and spoken to them.

 Saturday June 17. All day at Milo. Samuel & Lucy & mother went to the village to make calls & took tea at Albina's father's. I read to Josie some in the little book I carried here. I carried "Life of Bunyan" to Albina.
  Sabbath June 18. Mother, Lucy & Percie with little Mary & Sally's baby, self & baby remained at home - rest went to church and heard a Mr. Smith preach annihilation to the wicked. None of them enjoyed the preaching. Went home - were all busy enough with babies.

Monday June 19. Came back to Bangor - Sabra and all in the carriage. We stopped at noon at a private house where they sometimes put up people and had a most Excellent dinner - all clean and neat etc. Some tired at night. Samuel & I picked some checkerberry leaves to bring home to Mallie. A letter from you came also a letter from Dunbarton the first received since we were there. Father and mother had been to a ministers Convention at Concord and were detained in that way from writing, the letter, beside, was not put in the box so I did not get it as soon as otherwise. They were all well as usual, George at Pembroke, father to get a school for him next winter. I do wish he could do something besides keep school. They seem anxious to see me and yet willing I should do as is the best. I hardly know whether it is best for me to wait for Anne. I can not then be home before last week in July. I know it would be ever so much pleasanter to go with her, but will seem a long waiting to father & mother

Tuesday 20. Reading "Lamplighter". Raining part of the day. Two books at Fowler & bomb? come from you today. What made you think to send them? I am glad you did however.
Completed

Dunbarton Nett.
Sept. 1 - 5 - 1854. 
-  16. 1854                                                                                                  Dunbarton, Sept. 1, 1854.
My dearest Isaac,-

                         Last Friday my usual letter came not, but last night {Thursday} came one mailed Aug 22 at Mount Hawkins also one mailed the 26 inst. at St. Louis and the pictures. I opened the case and dear Isaac looked at me from underneath a broad oershadowing hat brim, just like himself, only a little browner methought  perhaps really so, perhaps only seeming, from the contrast with the light coat and hat. Then the additional hairs on the upper lip made it look at first a little older and fiercer perhaps, - but - I like it more & more - have about concluded it is a grand good picture. I had an idea you would shave, or rather not shave to suit yourself this summer, while away from us all. Now I should not admire that mustache or anybody else, and I like your face just as well without it, but am amazing glad you concluded to make an exhibition of the present condition of your countenance now I know how you are looking now. I have looked at that face so long tonight that it seems to stand out from the plate a living form, and so strange that it speaks not nor moves. O how it makes me long to see your very self. I am very glad you sent. It seems to me I can notice better you are really there living & acting, and I can see you again sometime. Dear little Mayo went to sleep tonight with it in both hands--had kissed it the last thing before the tiny eyelids
Completed

closed,  If you could only hear him say papa. it would do you good.  The little fellow has cared for himself much of the time this week has been a very good boy to day.  I do not take him to the table at all or find him from the table while we eat.  always give him his dish of bread & milk before we sit down. there he plays about and makes no trouble for any of us, till we are through.  Mother says she never saw a better boy at meal time.  He has a passion for daguerreotype & books.  wants every one he sees I have been making a book on purpose for him.  I took an old superannuated grammar and pasted pictures in it and he likes it much.
The day I wrote to you last I mailed a letter to Mallie & Lucy in answer to the one telling me of the coming of the little stranger among them  I am glad mother is there. Sorry they all feel so badly about Charles' remaining as not wonder poor Albina feels it.  Dont let him stay a great while longer will you. I am glad Col. Mason is coming in Sept, and shall be anxious to know what he says about your coming East. Can not you and Charles come together? I want to see Charles very much.  He seems so near to me because he was with us so much in Du Quoin  give love to him for me.  I think I shall write to Albina next week, and try as much as I can to comfort her.  She will know I can sympathise.  I have been reading out loud to the people this eve from the Independent.  I do like * very much as well as Cheever the first, best perhaps, his style is so simple so buoyant and enthusiastic. I always look for his signature first after a glance at the news.  But I must shut up this picture it has been looking at me all this while and go to rest.  I do think it is an excellent likeness.  Good night. says your loving Nettie.
Completed

Tuesday afternoon  Dinner just over and I have concluded to finish this and mail it this afternoon with a Daguerreotype  I went to Concord yesterday with father and had a fine ride to get it.  All who have seen it think it good and I hope you will like it though it does not seen to me very good.  The artist, Mr. Kimball of Concord thought it the best he could do Mother is resting and father also and Jenny busy about dinner dishes & Mayo is here with me in the sitting room and I cannot write very well he bothers me so.. He is all the while catching my finger or my pen or bringing some thing for me to see little rogue. He is some fretful too, but well I believe  He was a very good boy with mother yesterday while we were gone. I am afraid I shall not get a letter to day but if I get two Thursday as last week it will pay all and then I had the picture besides you know.  Wasn't I glad?  Mother is writing a little to you She takes a deal of comfort with little Mayo.  We had rain last Friday and Saturday, gentle and quite and fresh.  Saturday night it rained very powerfully indeed.  seemed to be pailsfull rather than drops.  The grass looks quite green since the potatoes probably so much refreshed by plentiful drinking, that they will grow a little more.  Father dug nine hills to day for about enough to last two days. very good, but small.  We are to have company from Concord tomorrow. Mr & Mrs. Smart & daughter.  Had letter from George last Saturday. Well  has a flourishing writing school and has charge of a reading class seems happy.  There have been
Completed

a great many fires all about us, mostly in the forests,  four or five buildings burned in Concord week before last.  and last week all the business part of Suncook (near Concord) was burned.  Every body and every thing was glad to see the heavens opened and rain descending.  I wonder if you have had any?

I have "Sunny Memories" . we are going to have it read aloud.  I have been reading Madam Roland We got Sept.  Harper Yesterday.  How much H.N.B. I mean * tells of his[Leuou?] possessions and very interesting tales hey are I think.  August is all gone is it not and Autumn is here.  We can hardly wish time to hasten even though we are away from each other. and you away from darling Mayo Little Percie is a good deal better now.  I tried to have Sabra help all she could but it was a problem I wished very much I could solve whether or not she was a help or a trouble to the good people there.  This was all the trouble I had while there.  I feared we were all making work for dear Lucy and Mallie.  I could not help enjoying myself though after all we all had some very pleasant hours & days together but I could not bear to think of being a burden myself, baby or girl. I should not have remained as long, had they not seemed to desire it.  It did not seem but a few days, either, to me.  Thermometer up to 84[degrees] to day [2 1/2 o'clock ) little wind and rather uncomfortable.

Last Sabbath was communion here full house.  Father preached.  John Parker up and at Church with Miss Stinson.  He is building a fine house for his bride.  Mrs Raymond & Her aunt here Sabbath day. She is not well.  Looks shadow like.  I must stop or not mail this to day
Your loving Nettie.
Completed

Dunbarton Nov. 12 th 54
Ducoign Dec. 2d        "

                                                                                                                       Dunbarton, Sabbath, Nov. 12, 1854.

My own dearest Isaac  

                       Here have I been writing for some time with dear little Mayo in my lap thinking about his dear very dear father. Now the little boy is playing with kitty running all about the floor, and trying to talk, so I take the time to write while he does not need me. I have been at meeting all day - mother went last sabbath. We had not a very full house for it rained very steadily all day long - moistening the glad earth and replenishing the exhausted springs. Last Tuesday came your long letters telling me about the sad accident. The next morning with my bonnet on ready for a ride to Concord, I scribbled a note to you to take with me and mail at C. Yesterday came yours of Nov. 7 mailed at St. Louis, and a good one from sister Mallie. They are enjoying housekeeping much- both her sisters probably to be there this winter. She said my Isaac wrote her "some beautiful lines in a letter to Eliab". She says, "how I do like Isaac." Mallie is a dear, kind sister and excellent wife, I think. - and that little Percie is getting fat and healthy again. Is'nt it good? And all that exposure and labor & loss of sleep has not made you sick! I do think it is wonderful. How can I help saying "My cup runneth over" when I think of that accident and of your safety. It makes me feel as though you surely would be kept; and we shall meet again to be thankful and happy together. Is Mitchell getting well? How good that he too was so little injured

[left-hand side] I do not think I had better get a cloak now this winter. You know that large warm cape like my brown Thibet dress. That will answer every purpose. Almost every one wears furs - round neck and wrists tipped, and I do not know what else they style thus  -- but I have a muff and that is enough I think. I like you to have you tell me about dress, for I like your taste.
Completed

I am glad too it happened by no carelessness of any of your men. The case seems to be one they had no power to control. It seems the Du Quoin people are not long without a preacher. I am glad they have on that "knows something" and has somewhat of his own to live on, it is fortunate. Will he begin preaching at the station? I have just finished Actes 26 & 27 in the French Testament - have read too some in Independent of Nov 9 to mother . How quick your last letter came, mailed Nov 7, and here Nov 11. I never received one quite so soon before. I wonder if you would not get mine sooner if I sent them via St. Louis? George is at home now, but will not be for long, I suppose. I love to have him here. Jenny will be home a week at Thanksgiving - will come the Saturday before. I shall want my dear Isaac there. How can I enjoy it without you - but I'll try; and then I'll have my real Thanksgiving when you come!

 I have just now lain little Mayo to rest. I have been thinking for some days it would be better to put him in bed and leave him to go to sleep by himself, so last night I began so doing. I should think he cried more than half an hour very hard. It made me almost relent but I did not go to him, and he went to sleep by himself at last. To night I did the same. He cried about one minutes as if his heart was broken - when he found I had left him again, then a few mournful ma, ma, and a long drawn sigh and he reposed himself to sleep. I stood at the door and watched him. I do not think he will cry at all next time.
  Monday afternoon. It has just stopped raining but is closely still. This is the third day it has rained. Father is having some fruit trees set out and Mayo is
Completed

watching the men at work and enjoying it wonderfully. We did not go to Pembroke last Wednesday - only to Concord. The weather grew so cold before we were at Concord that father dared not go farther so he came directly home - but I stayed to do some shopping and to hear Rev. J.C. Fletcher lecture in the Evening before the young men's "Christian Association" - subj. of the Lecture "Our Country". Mr. Fletcher has resided in Europe some years - is a fine speaker.

  I got a velvet bonnet and paid therefore $8.00. That is enough is'nt it for one bonnet. My conscience almost smites me. It makes $13.00 dollars kist for bonnets this year - beside my travelling one. I do not think I have been very saving this season, but I have not intended to be wasteful! I enjoyed the ride to Concord much. Grand old Kearsarge seemed only four or five miles away, at most - hoary with snow, and the sun shining full upon it. I never saw it to so fine advantage before, just so with the whole range of hills about us. I would have gone twice the distance to behold such a scene. Since the rain the grass has grown green as in spring almost. George came home Thursday from Pembroke. I came from Concord the same day with the mail carrier in an old rickety wagon, a horse who very evidently had ribs and the most eccentric driver you ever saw - bright though & strictly honest & upright. He weilded the limb of a tree for a whip!  I got home safely by three in the P.M. & little Mayo was glad enough
Completed

to see me. It is the first night I have been away from him since you left. He was as good a boy mother reported as could be, better than when his mother is here! Mr. Amos Hadley - once teacher here you remember, waited upon us to the Evening lecture. I spent the night at Esq. Kimball's, an old friend of mother's, since Thursday as I did Wednesday with Mrs. Smart. I imagine you have heard me speak of her. I used to board with her when I attended school in Concord. 

    Last Friday, I baked some in A.M. and after we dined, & Mayo had his nap George took him and me and we called at Capt. Stinson's at a Mr. Wilson's and at Harris Rider's. Mayo was good at the two first places, but at Mr. Rider's for some reason he acted like a little fury--cried and stamped & kicked and shook his head and exhibited clearly that he had a will of his own - spoilt our call entirely - shall have to go again I reckon and leave him at home.
   Harris' little boy has been very sick with scarlet fever. He and his mother went to Salem to visit, and he was taken sick there. She only came about a week since. The little boy looks very pale yet. Is'nt Mr. Season on the line often these days & Almost every letter speaks of your meeting him somewhere.  You say  Big Muddy Bridge is done - is Little Muddy too? I do not care a bit how soon it is all done. But I shall not look for you till Jan. lest I be disappointed.
  I wonder what Mistress Keyes thinks of going to the station to live? I expect I ought to send my love to her. Won't you give some to her next time you call. You know she really was very kind indeed to me when I was sick in June. How much she did for little Mayo - and I cannot help remembering it. I don't think the woman is as good as she might be, and who is? "Give every one his due and who would 'scape whipping"?  George goes tomorrow to the Institute - it lasts ten days. I hope to go down some.

[left-hand side upside down] My bonnet is a black velvet - a very rich piece with garnet & white flowers inside. I wonder if you will like it - I am afraid!
Completed

Antoinette
Bangor
June 9, 1855                                                                At Lucy's Friday morning

                                                                                           June 9, 1855.

My dearest Isaac,

     Here we are, Mayo & self in the front chamber at Lucy's sitting close by the window. It rained yesterday all the P.M. and all last night and is cloudy this morning, but I imagine will be pleasant by noon. Lucy has been cake and I have been reading aloud to her from a Library book. "Modern Agitations." I have read sketches of James Russel Lowell, Fred. Douglass N.P. Rogers. etc. Mayo is close at my side playing with my combs & brush. He seems happy as need be here much more so than at the other house. Lucy and I went down town yesterday about ten o'clock and home about one, leaving the two little folks with Lizzie & Ellen. They were just as good as could be - both asleep when we came home. Lizzie had given them dinner at twelve and got them both asleep herself. She is first best for taking care of children - devises all manner of way and means to please them. Lucy says she feels perfectly safe to leave P.P. with her much more than with Ellen. Lucy and I scoured the city for pretty shawls yesterday, and found among a new lot just received at "Hatch and
Completed

Thompson's" two almost precisely alike that suited us, only the fabric was more than either of us wanted to give- $6.00. They were very willing to take the "yallor" one back again - so I sent it & paid the difference and have a shawl I like and humbly and sincerely hope & trust you will like it too. I went to bed & to sleep after you left Wednesday morning - had a nice nap. We had not breakfast till after seven because nobody was up to eat. Sammy Ely was latest of all. You know Eliab waked him just before you started - that disturbed his slumber so greatly that he overslept - felt sadly about being so late at the store. After breakfast I righted matters up stairs preparatory to deserting. The Porter cart took the trunks before two and shortly after Mayo and his mother trudged up here leaving Mallie somewhat long visaged - promised to see her every pleasant day. You know I hoped to go to Maternal Meeting in P.M., but could not arrange to leave Mayo, because Lizzie had the promise of going and I knew he would not be contented with Ellen, so I stayed with him. Lucy, Mallie and Lizzie went. Had a funny time as well as good, from Lucy's description. Lucy and Mallie went down town before meeting and to Mr. Wells for Tomato plants after meeting - did not get home till past six. Is'nt it wonderful that Lucy can endure so much? She had headache yesterday morning quite severely, but going down town
Completed

cured it entirely! Mayo cried every night a little on going to bed - but guess he will just get over it. Lucy says she forgot when you were up Tuesday that you were going away for so long and her lips ached because she did not kiss you. I had a fine sleep yesterday after dinner - so I did Wednesday. Was'nt that a good girl. Mrs. Harlow was in last evening told of a colored man in the city - just escaped from bondage. Mr. Shepard had been up to tell about him and see if some families would not volunteer to board him - so save his hotel bill. He is trying to get money to buy his family out of slavery. He will spend some days at Mr. Harlow's, and perhaps here also. Lizzie goes down every night to sleep with Maria. You left the little Inkstand after all. How do you without it? I wonder when I shall get a letter. I am almost impatient now. I did not ask you when you should write. Knew you would write as soon as you could. It seems strange enough to be without you. I can hardly set myself about anything yet. The Tomato plants came last night and Samuel set them out in all the rain. Mr. Wells had sold all his best ones.

    Lucy sends her extraordinary affections and sisterly love, and wants you to take care of yourself and not get sick.
   I am going down to see Maria a little while - so I must hasten. I have not half made the letters and have not time to
Completed

look over this or, the note to Anne, so do be kind enough to forget the mistakes and be? and remember it comes right from the heart of

                                                                                              Your Nettie
  I have written in the big book every day! Mayo said very sorrowfully this morning "Faver done away - Mayo taint see him." He has asked a good many times to go up stairs and find you. When we came up Wednesday he said he was coming to see Percie and find father. Sometimes he says "faver done down' teet" and sometimes goin "to 'cago" {Chicago}. I am going to carry Mallie some Pepper grass and we are going to have some for dinner. "by by"
                                                                                                                                                                                                  Nettie.
Completed

Antoinette
Bangor

        June 14 1855
                                                                                                               Bangor, Maine
                                                                                             Thursday morn June 14, 1855.

Dearest Isaac,

                         I got up ever so early this morning, by the way I've seen the sunrise about every day since you left, thinking I would write to you the very first thing, but I have done a number of things first.
         I wrote a letter to Augusta Walker, at Barnstead (you remember one came from her just before you left) then Mayo waked and I washed & fed him - then at breakfast - and then Lucy and I went into the garden sometime, and over to see Mr. Harlow's garden & down to Mr. Page's beside. Mrs. Harlow talked some as usual - told about her 'sturtiums and Springos etc. But Miriam Page amused me most. She a perfect little paddy. Did you ever see her? And yet she is kind & good hearted, I imagine.
    Your second letter gladdened me yesterday - dated Lewistown, Pen.. How would I delight to see the mountains with you - how grand it must be. I want to know the story of the Alleghanies - you are beyond them by this time mayhap. I have written two letters to Elyria. Last one mailed Monday. We had a letter from Anna Monday. She is expecting you this week. Greatly disappointed at the result of the plans for visiting - thunks Milo have peculiar attractions.
Completed

I am sorry for her disappointment.

  Tuesday was showery all the A.M. cleared away about noon. Mayo's third eye tooth is through. I walked to Maria's in PM stayed till five and walked back. O how much good the showers have done! Everything shines in beauty out of doors. Yesterday Lucy and I went out and weeded a long time and enjoyed it finely. Then Eliab came up and I went down with him & Mallie & I went down town. After dinner Maria came up here and spent the P.M. and we had a fine time talking. Eliab has hired, I believe, a two seated carriage & two horses to go to Milo. He concluded it would be about as cheap as to go by stage and so much pleasanter & then we should have the carriage to go to Brownville. E. thinks to be gone two nights I believe, and we shall persuade him to stay longer if we can. Samuel will go up to come home with Lucy. I am writing very hurriedly because Lizzie wants to be studying & I ought to be caring for Mayo as soon as I can. Lizzie goes to singing school two afternoons in the week. She wants very much to go to Milo with us, but must stay with Ellen & Samuel I suppose and there would not be room either with the three babies. Lucy & I could not possibly carry our boys in our laps all the way without some back-breaking. I expected to go in stage all the while, but it would have been hard. I dreaded it - shall send the baggage by
Completed

stage. How I should enjoy travelling with you this pleasant month. I should like to be in Du Quoin when you are there. My love to Mrs. Wall if you see her there. I do not believe you will be gone two months will you? At any rate I will not think you will.

  We think some of going clear to Brownville before we stop - go the first pleasant day next week. I imagine though, we shall stay the first night at Milo. I have written so often since you left that there seems to be nothing at all worth writing - but I thought I would write for you might not have anything till you get to Du Quoin. Mayo is some fretful - the last eye tooth troubles him. He and P.P. have some little troubles in company but with a little watching they do pretty well. My greatest trouble is I cannot find time to sew! I thought I would tell you, since you might be able to contrive some plan for my relief! Is'nt the Family Robinson funny - such improbabilities and fortunate occurrences were very remarkable - just the book for a boy. Mayo says "father gone" Mayo taint see him."
                      Lucy sends great regards & sisterly remembrances.
                                                   Lovingly, your own
                                                                                 Nettie
Completed

Antoinette
Bangor June 16, 1855

                                                                                                    Saturday Eve, June 16, 1855.

My dearest Isaac,

                            I can hardly do without you tonight. If you could just drop in and spend the Sabbath, would'nt I like it? I wonder where you are now? A nice letter came to day mailed the 11 inst. {last Monday} dated "Good Intent Hotel" etc. What a curious name for a Public House. How good you are, as usual, about writing. It is such a comfort. I am very glad you are enjoying your journey so much as you seem to be. Can't help feeling glad too that you think of the Eyes you left behind, and sometimes wish they could look with you on beautiful flowers and grand mountains. How I should delight to be with you, if my place were not here - but I am ever so happy here. Lucy and I are sitting by ourselves in the sitting room, or rather she is on the lounge resting. Samuel gone to rehearsal, the little ones sleeping. This morning I rode down town with Maria almost entirely for the ride. I got some sugar plums & peppermints to carry to the children at Milo. Lucy, Maria & I are all going to carry a cap to Mother - so she will be nicely supplied. I have been packing trunks this P.M. beside taking care of Mayo, washing & ironing his sack and various items of preparation. Lizzie went
Completed

to singing school this P.M.- goes twice a week.

  She does not relish the idea of being left here -wants to go to. But Ellen says she should not be willing to stay without Lizzie, and beside there seems no way for her to go except by stage and that is hardly worth while. Lucy thinks she shall stay only a week, Maria three or four. I shall stop at Milo, and I guess Maria will make first visit there. It has been a fine day, today, but is raining hard now- only a shower, I imagine, however. How much rain we have had of late. All yesterday A.M. it rained. I walked down to Maria just before it began and had to stay till Samuel came to dinner. But the P.M. was pleasant.
   Thursday, Samuel went to Hampden on business, and Lucy & P.P. went for the ride.Gone till six o'clock. A Miss Coffran- Lirrio Coffran of Dover and her father spent that night here. I believe they said you boarded there once. At any rate Samuel did. Very pleasant sort of people. It is ten o'clock and Samuel not here yet. I believe I am tired and sleepy enough to go to bed - good night, dear Isaac.
    Monday 18 June Four P.M.} Here we are in mother's room at Milo.- Lucy & P.P., Maria, Eliab & Gertie, Albina & Mary. Mother dear, self & Mayo quite a room full. There is a girl out in the kitchen- came Saturday - name is Ferris. I hope she will prove a
Completed

good girl. Charles is out making smulty fence on north side of the road near the Cedar Swamp. The little Charlie & Josie at school. We started a little before eight this morning, got here at three, come slowly to enjoy it - had two grey horses and a very easy carriage. Mallie has two carpet bags, Lucy a valise & carpet bag, me a carpet bag - stage brought the trunks and I guess Charles will get them to night. They are at the corner. Had a nice view & do not any of us feel much tired, not even Lucy. All the trouble was Lucy & I wanted Samuel & Isaac. It seems such a half way sort of business to have the biggest half of yourself gone, when one has something to enjoy. Mayo seems quite at home already. I just went out for him & found him coaxing Kitty out of doors. He said ' tum Kitty, tum out doors, out doors, oh yeth" Kitty  could'nt resist it. The other day he came and kissed me ever so many times and then said "there, dat all, I beeve (believe) dat all." and ran away. He talks about "dear father" every  day. There are some misquitoes here.  I am afraid the children will get scarred faces.  

   Yesterday Lucy went to meeting in A.M. and Mr. Field preached again. I seem fated not to hear him. I went in P.M. & heard Prof. Shepard - not quite so interesting as usual. Text "God loveth a cheerful giver." It is a lovely day to day - we could'nt have had a better - fair and comfortable. All ever well here Mother looks finely- she has just finished reading
Completed

your last letter. Have not heard anything since you left till we came except by Eliab who wrote a week ago Friday.

  Eliab will go to Brownville tomorrow. Mallie Lucy and mother with him and I guess they will all return with him Wednesday. Then Mallie & mother * I will go up again by & by. Mallie wants to make the first visit here and still to go with Eliab. Mallie says it looks nicely here. She likes the grove. Mayo joggles me vigorously now & then. I do hope Charles will bring home a letter from you to night. He has just come home with his shirt wet enough with perspiration to be rung - guess he has worked too hard. I must hasten. We feast on bread & milk already do come & help speedily.
                                     O so much love, from your own
                                                                            Nettie

Letter from Dunbarton Saturday - all well - George coming to Hiltesy this week- goes to College 1st Sept.
Completed

Antoinette
Brownville
July 18, 1855

                                                                                                         Brownville Wednesday July 18. 1855

My own dear husband, Isaac-

                     This morning came two dear letters from your very dear self one of July 2, the other July 4. from Du Quoin & Du Buque - O so good! how they made my heart leap for joy. But it makes me sad to think how few letters will reach you from me. It has been such self denial not to write every time I had news from you. I only wrote twice to Du Quoin thinking it not possible you could get any more. Then I wrote one directing to Chicago thinking you would stop there as you came north. That I suppose you will not get. Last Thursday, July 12, came yours mailed at Centralia, requesting me to write to St. Paul. It was a whole week later in reaching me than you supposed it would be, so I wrote very hurriedly to send back
Completed

to the village, and go out by the next mail - a perfect scrawl of a letter written in all the hurry and bustle of a house full of company, little Mayo pulling my sleeve, and all sorts of annoyances. I fear it was hardly worth the sending. I thought all the while too that you would not get it - now I think you will get it and that I might have written another by the next mail, but it is too late now to write again to St. Paul - only a few days and one a Sabbath, to send in from Brownville. So I will send this to Elyria I suppose. That sounds like you would be homeward bound ere long. What will Mayo say when you come? He will know who you are this time. He is a perfect comfort to me when you are away. He comes and says "Mayo want - Mayo sunny bonnet on." Then he runs out and snatches a few "posies" - clover and buttercups - and runs in, for the flies are too thick to stay many minutes. The other day, he broke a flower from the stock and brought it to me saying sadly "Mama, - put 'it on aden". He has not
Completed

forgotten the doings of the "Fourth". When he thinks of it he says I {dess guess} I better (hurra hulla} now." He has funny ideas, all his own, about measuring his love. He loves father "four bushels, and a tow cow and a lammie and some bossys" . Loves Jamie "four bushels and a cow and a horse." Loves the Lammie "four bushels and a horse & fours doors and a bow-wow". The preface is always four bushels. He talks about Percie & Gertie, says they are "gone done away, to Bandor" and tells how much he loves them. It is hard for him to be in doors so much - but the flies are too bad for him to be out. The top of his head is covered & recovered with bites as it is - so his neck and ears. We hope they will depart soon. They have been more troublesome for some days - perhaps have arisen in great wrath because their time is short. Mr. Rider says they normally leave in July & I think they might to retire to private life & reflect & repent. They need to do so as much as the President almost.
Completed

I thought you could not help liking Northern Illinois. I have not forgotten the region of Lockport, Homer Elgin, St. Charles etc.  O! the old place at Du Quoin. Is'nt it too cruel to have it so deserted, and over run with weeds. I cannot bear to think it is so. It is marvellous how vegetation thrives there - your tale of the peach trees at the bottom of the garden is almost beyond belief. I do not think I should care to go there to see it in its present condition.

    Well I must tell you somewhat about the "Brownvillians at Riderville" as Lucy says. and their deeds. Let me see Eliab come the day I wrote last. It as Thursday. Friday he rose betimes, breakfasted on strawberries and milk   ("top o last night" - he asked Almeda for, and got it). and then with you fishing tackle he went horseback to the Lake alone. Home about ten - not even a glorious nibble from the fishes - but Ah me! the flies! His face was bitten badly and poor Maria felt sadly to see him so disfigured, but nae' the less there are worse things in the world than flies. Then after dinner we all, with torches & turpentine clothes, went out to pick some berries on stems to send fresh to Lucy. - got a peck box full of nice ones. Between two & three
Completed

he started for Milo and we have heard nothing from them since. They intended to spend the night at Charles' - go to Bangor Saturday. I should think from what Eliab said Samuel's Lumber was coming out fully as bad as they feared leaving him considerably worse than nothing. Sad is'nt it - but it is well he is engaged as he is in so good business. Lissie Harmon who taught the school here this summer & boarded here helping night & morning  - is here still, now that school is done, helps Almeda all the time. A very good & pretty girl indeed. Almeda has plenty to do. I see five big loaves of brown bread on the table now, beside all the wheat, & she bakes twice a week  - so this is only for half a week & such washing both as regards quantity and quality, I never saw before. Mr. Rider is haying now has a hired man most of the time beside Elbridge & Mills. They began
[top, upside down] {I have written all this in great haste to send by Mr. Rider this P.M. - sat down as soon as your letters came and I had read them. So I had very little time in which to write. Love to Anna and all the dear ones at Elgin.}
Completed

a week ago Monday. Mr. Rider seems very well  thinks his face no worse - no better - either that I know of. I think it likely he may show it to Dr. McRuen again this Autumn. 1300 grafts have been inserted in the apple orchard north of the house this spring & summer. The trees look finely.

    I go out to walk whenever the flies will permit. I have a fine necklace of bites. There are comparatively few strawberries this year. None near here except in the orchard and those are all gathered now. We picked some ripe currants yesterday. Mother sits close by reading a newspaper. Mayo is lying on the floor studying intently an old Geography. He will look at one picture ten minutes or more. Likes pictures better than almost anything else. He says "Now I lay me" very prettily now and always wants to say "Dear Father" next. I could not think that he meant when he first said it, but soon found he meant "Our Father" - Mother has
Completed

not felt so well since the warm weather came. She says it makes her feel "so shiftless and lazy." She will not call it anything else. I think she is rather pining to get back to Milo, to watch over her tomatoes & roses & those little houseplants - Charlie & Josie & Mary though she seems happy enough here.

  She will not stay more than a week longer I imagine. I do not know whether I shall go when she does or not. Almeda says I better stay till you come so that you can come for us and she can see you. Shall I do so? The only trouble is I want to see you just as soon as you get to Milo. It will not make much difference I know.
  Mayo came near tipping over the table with the five big brown bread loaves on, it all in iron pans directly onto his own little self. Mother & I were both by and caught the table just after the loaves began to slide.
 I have had a nice letter from Anna and was thinking to answer it to day, but she will hear from me when you get this, and so it may be better to wait a few days before writing to her.

[left-hand side and top] A letter from home to day too - Mother can hardly bear it that we do not come there this Fall. Father has his old trouble diarrhea to some extent - not so bad yet as last season. Mother as usual only a little tired with nursing? when she wrote. Father just getting over an attack of rhumatism.
Completed

you see, dearest, my heart is so full, and I could say so much about our three years, that I can hardly say anything. I knew you would remember the day, and I wanted to write, but knew not when a letter would find you there. So I wrote a great long one, three or four times over, in my head, and tried to be as contented as possible. Please do not speak again of anything undone on your part towards making the years happy. What more could you have done, my inmost heart thanks you, my precious friend, for all your love and care. I used to feel sometimes. when sick at Du Quoin, that I never should see New England again or live to love you & little Mayo - though I knew not the Dr's true thought of me.  But I know it was your own gentleness, sympathy, watching and nursing, more than all things else that gave me strength & made me well again. I mean, of course, with Our Heavenly Father's favor & blessing. I too, dear Isaac, believe it is my will to be a true wife & mother, and I would turn away from all the sad mistakes I make, and the manifold causes I have for regrets, & press forward toward the mark. God will help us both in every duty - and you know not how much your loveing & constant overlooking of my faults aids me in striving to be what I ought.

   That we may live not only for ourselves and ours but to make the world better is the wish of your ever loving Nettie.
Completed

Antoinette
Jan. 12 1856

                                                                                                                     Dunbarton N.H.
                                                                                                                     Saturdy Jan. 12 - 1856

My dearesr,

   Baby in my arms, I sit me down to write. I mailed a letter to you last Tuesday and one the to mother also. - yours to Du Quoin and hers to Elyria. In the first letter I mailed to Elyria were enclosed ten dollars from the lost Pocket Book, which was found. I hope these all reached you safely. The babies are well except that Willis has a cold which he got from me I expect - do not know how else he could get it. He must be more easily affected than Wilder. He seems hoarse - guess he will get over it soon. He is in my arms and Wilder asleep on sofa. I do not know how I got cold but I have a little. The cold & perhaps in part the
Completed

babies mouths have made my breasts sore - so that it hurts me to nurse. I am preparing borax and alum for them. I forgot to mention the recept of your second letter Tuesday. Also we have one from Lucy Pond, saying Jenny was some better. Thermometer was 5o  below zero, Tuesday Eve. but more than 80 persons were out to singing school. Wind blew tremendously. Mayo is well. He says "that'll be the bestest" "Mover, what tums nextess"? Babies laugh and play more than ever use hands more. Mayo wakes up in the night and says "I doad boy, Senfuf" - Can you find the Sabbath talks about Jeesus & bring home to him?

  Are you going to arrange for a crop somewhere, next summer, before you come home? I remember you said you wished you had last season, or something to that effect. Wilder sits in a rocking chair - tied in. He is a most excellent
Completed

baby - Willis would be just as good if he felt quite as well.

  I want to write ever so much but cannot. I wrote to Lucy by last mail. We weighed babies on the 10th  Willis 13 3/4 lbs. Wilder some more than 14 lbs. I called at Mr. Caldwell's and Safford's when father went to the Office Thursday. I shall direct this to Du Quoin.
                                                                                                 Your own Loving
                                                                                                                     Nettie.
Completed

Antoinette
Jan. 21. 1856                                                                                               Dunbarton, Jan: 21, 1856.
My Dearest

                        Another letter I received from your dear self (dated Elyria Jan 15) last Saturday. One also from Almeda enclosing one to you from Elbridge which I shall enclose in this. Before now you are in Chicago I suppose, safe & comfortable I do so hope. What snow storms we do have in these days - but yesterday (Sabbath) for a wonder it did storm and we had quite a full meeting. We get along nicely the cold nights - cold days do not so much but keep the dear babies both warm. They and Mayo seem well as usual. I read your letter aloud with the message to Mayo. He noticed it of his own accord, and listened with all possible attention, and when I stopped he looked as happy as boy could and laughed one of his hearty, happy laughs. He is quite
Completed

a good boy, as a general thing - as kind to the "liv bovers" as his quick, ardent nature will let him be. He tries to be very careful - sometimes goes whispering & tiptoeing about the room when they are asleep. Glad mother was so comfortable. She ought to have had another shawl on the journey. Did'nt she need one? I do not think you will need to send me money. I should rather you would not. It will not be long before you will be home - some would call me foolish, but I do keep longing to see you! I have written every day in the Record Book and happened to do just as you thought of proposing about it - two days to a page.

 I looked over the Expense Book & as I reckon, there should have been about ($65.00) sixty five dollars in it instead of $55.00
 I mailed a bit of a note to you from
Completed

Manchester by Mr. Buruk ? last Friday morn - to Chicago, in hopes you might get it before going to Du Quoin.

 You spoke of your presentiment of evil after leaving D. I had the same. I could not help feeling sad & anxious and uneasy without knowing why. It seemed when you were starting as if I could not let you go. It is singular - I think - I could not decide in my own mind how you came on the floor when mother found you. O how very very much we ought to be thankful. Surely our year has begun with "goodness & mercy". 

Eve- Mayo gone to bed. He says "tell Faver, I dood boy" I had a fine time talking & reading to him from six till seven this eve & the babies slept. We sup at half past five now. He askes a great many times in a day for "tories" and to be read to. In this play I often hear him talking over to himself what he
Completed

has heard. It is amusing to see little Wilder go to sleep - sings himself to sleep almost always. Makes a little noise just as long as he possibly can. There the darlings both lie one on each end of the sofa. I know you long to see them! They both waked up just here and *Asenath & I have just got them to sleep again. I am going to send the letter from Almeda to mother. Mr. Rider has been setting his Estate - deeded the whole to Mills - providing that he shall furnish him & his wife with a dwelling place, suitable food & clothing & care in sickness. Almeda was daily expecting to start for Bangor or Boston. The letter was mailed the 14 Jan. His face seemed better but the place under the jaw worse. Walter cut his leg above the knee in the woods Thanksgiving day and has been quite sick ever since - not able to go even with crutches yet. Elbrdige given up making shovel handles getting out of the woods as fast as he can what he had made. Lizzie going to school. James at the village at school. Almeda not seen him for five weeks. Almeda is having too hard a time I fear. I wrote to mother by Saturday mail.

                                                             Good night, my own dearest.
                                                                              Lovingly, Nettie.

Asenath is a Biblical name from Book of Genesis -- further references seem to be to Aseneth and Adeneth but the spelling used most often is Asenath.
Completed

Antoinette
Jan 24 1856

                                                                                                                      By Sitting Room
                                                                                                                        Thursday Jan. 24, 1856

My dearest,- 

              Your letter mailed at Chicago last Friday, the 18th came by Tuesday's mail. The same day I mailed one to you, to Chicago, and enclosed one from Elbridge Rider. I'll write a little to Chicago to day and not write again till next week, hoping in the meantime, to receive another from you and perhaps you will say direct to Elyria. Then shall I rejoice! I wonder what the next chapter of accidents will be. What a journey you have had from the very beginning. But thus far you have been preserved. Is'nt it blessed to trust Our Heavenly Father? To feel that He, in infinite wisdom will direct & guide all our way. I do long to have you home, though we succeed nicely
Completed

with babies and all things else. We have had some very cold weather this week, but yesterday was fine and so is today - mild & clear. I went into singing school from eight to nine last night- haven't been so great a crowd this long time.  The hall was crowded full - great many came to hear. I have not felt as well as usual for some days. I do not know but I must conclude that I am a dyspeptic, though I do not love to think so. Almost every thing I eat hurts me, or else something else does. Last Tuesday we had calls from four ladies, and yesterday Miss Hannah Marshall & Mrs. Enoch Marshall, & Mr. Jonathan Ireland's wife, and a Miss Straw were here. So it is about every day. The babies have both, within a day or two begun sucking their thumbs taking apparently all possible comfort in so doing. What must I do about
Completed

it? Anything? I think Willie has grown fat some since you left. We have a shawl and pillow on the floor & Wilder lies there kicking mightely.  Willie is there too now. They do not look badly at all. Mayo is on the floor too playing with their feet. He grows more careful about hurting them.

      Mrs. Kimball is just alive, no more. I must stop.
                                                         Always your own
                                                                     Nettie.

Father & mother send love. I think mother seems better. Jennie has begun studying at Uncle Pond's - but cannot study much - not more than 2 hours pr day. Mayo seems well now - is out doors running on the platform.
Completed

Antoinette
Feb. 6, 1856

                                                                                                                 Dunbarton, N.H.
                                                                                                                 Wednesday Feb. 6, 1856
                     My dearest,-
              Before me lie your last two letters, dated Jan. 24th & 29th. the latter reached me yesterday. Written on your birthday. You seem to think yourself quite advanced in years. Dear Isaac I do not mean if I can help it that you shall have any more so much care and wakefulness? at home, as you have had, to make you grow old before the right time. It should not be. I hope you may live many years yet, and live not in vain and for naught. Will we not try to help each other in the right way- the path of wisdom. It seems to me I do my part most miserably. Not a day passes but I think of that wonderful escape, and of the obligations we are under to pour out our whole

[left hand side and over letter]Jenny is very anxious you should stop and see her on the way home. Poor girl, she feels sadly about her health. It seems as though she could hardly submit to it. I hope you can stop a little while for her sake.
7th Mayo sits by the sofa pouring over an old book, says to himself " I studying Geogadale." He has been talking to the babies this morning. You would laugh to hear  - "Darling littul baby, won't you tell me a 'tory. Haven't you dot any more tories to tell"
Nettie, you naughty girl, why did'nt you take another piece of paper instead of writing this twice over.
Completed

hearts in praise and thanksgiving to the bounteous giver of all good. Were you not saved, to be useful; to do great good in the world? So may it be!

  We were sorry you forgot that name. It was Wingate. I suppose you are almost ready by this time to leave Chicago and start homeward - at least I do hope so. I thought I would direct this to Elyria, taking it for granted that you would leave Chicago soon if you have not already.
  You speak of being tempted to live at Du Coigne. I do not dislike the idea only I should like to be as near to my father & mother as possible - and I think the climate farther north would suit you better and perhaps me also. It seems a pity not to have your money invested there, and not to have your part of the business saved for as it ought to be.  I have been out this P.M. to make some calls. Mayo went with me, and a better boy never was. He enjoyed it
Completed

greatly. He carried a large apple to an old lady (Mrs. Stinson) and presented it very prettily. One lady asked him if he would give her one baby. He out a long face on and said "No, I tan not 'par one of my bovers." You know he always used to say "Yeth." What made him change I don't know. He always persists that the picture of little Samuel in his song book is "dear Uncle Samuel." Mrs. Wilson called here to night and she asked him to come & see her . "Well - I'm - very - busy, now" was his answer. He has an idea of beginning every sentence with well, just now. He speaks of you about every night when I put him to bed. Sometimes says "when will my faver tum." Once he asked if "Dod was with his faver." But I need not write all this, when I hope to tell you all so soon. The babies know their mother evidently now. Willis nearly scolded at mother the other day because she had no
Completed

spectacles on. I think you will say he has altered more than Wilder. They are both just as good as babies need be. I had a letter from Lucy last Saturday. We have five letters by that mail and I mailed one to Anna. I have been writing to Lucy today.

Did I tell you Mrs. Kimball was dead. She died Feb. 1. For thirty six hours before she died she gave no sign of life except to breathe - could not move a finger. It was a very distressing death. Father has gone into the singing school this eve. There is to be another concert in about a week.
   I am so glad Banks is elected speaker. Is'nt it good - best! The babies are both fast asleep this evening. I seem to be quite at leisure. O I long to talk to you so much! I seem to know you will be here by next week certainly. Then we will rejoice together. I have been making cake. We expect a Miss Allison from Canada here sometime this week. She is visiting in town.
 All send love- but most of all from
                            Your own loving Nettie.
Completed

Elyria, Feb. 26. 1856

My dearest:

      Sabbath evening- Mother on the lounge resting. Mary Rich reading. Eliab gone to ?, children all sleeping - wish we knew just what you were doing, or at least whether you are safe in DuQuoin. I have had two letters - one from Gallion, and one from Mattoon - sorry we all are for your delays - hope you will be able to make connections so as to get home by Saturday night at any rate. Eliab thinks to go tomorrow morning. He spent most of yesterday at Charles' - Hattie DeWitt was here to supper with him, and he went back with her about eight, and stayed an hour or two. Hattie had a long story to tell him. I did not go out to day - it is very wet walking. Albina & Charles & Anna & George stopped after meeting till almost night. We had a good time
Completed

singing. I sent the question books & papers to S.S. Mr. Ely superintended. Albina said he "had a good deal of swing." But she said, moreover, that he did well, and everything went on nicely. Mao had, with great pains, printed a few lines to send to you. Wilder wanted to write, but did not get about it till too late. Mother seems to have taken cold, and does not feel very well.

A little boy of the widow Proctors died at our neighbor Proctor's last week and was buried Friday. scarlet fever. Mrs. Bennets two children both sick. She sent here for help. I sent her to Mr. Hitchcock.
   I like Lyra Americana very much.
                                                 Good night - you Nettie

Monday morn - all comfortable. Eliab just ready to start: He will mail this for me. The boys have been very good - Josie & all.
Completed

Dunbarton, May 22 - 1856.

Dearest Isaac,-

                  I will write a few lines to send by this afternoon's mail. Father and mother are gone to North Dunbarton to make calls etc. Willie is sleeping and Wilder playing on the floor. Asenath finishing her ironing Jenny sewing & talking as fast as possible. Of course I have been almost lost without your dear self & Mayo though so fully employed with the babies as not to be lonely at all. I cannot tell how many times I fancied I heard Mayo yesterday. The babies seem as well as when you left. - perhaps better. They slept very well. Wilder only waked once, and did not cry at all during the night.
Completed

Willie waked three times and cried some. I rose at half past four & builded a fire and took the babies up - warmed milk, etc. and they both went to sleep again till after breakfast. Asenath washed and dressed one. She helps very much with the babies - much more than when you are here & without my asking her at all - so it is not hard for me you perceive. Mrs. Tafford and Ellen were here yesterday P.M. Bradford Burnham reached home in fine season without any trouble. Did Anna get a view of Monadnock during the ride? I forgot Mayo's milk. Did he ask for it or did he get along comfortably without? I hope you will not find him troublesome to yourself or Lucy or anybody else. Asenath will stay till you return from Maine but says she would like to go
Completed

as soon as we can find other help. I do so dislike to change. There are several reasons why I should prefer not to have a Stinson girl and I know of no one else about here. I suppose I had better be making some inquiry & secure some one as soon as possible - had I not?

  I suppose you are about reaching your journey's end now. If it was right or would do any good I could easily wish I were with you and could see Lucy & Percie and all the rest. I think about you all and rejoice in your joy. Hope you find Lucy much better than you expected.
   Mr. Colby & Rogers are here to day at work - were here yesterday also - have taken the leach away and spaded the corner of the garden. 
    Willie wakes - good bye dearest. Love to all - Kiss Mayo and tell
Completed

him to be very careful to be good and not worry & trouble Aunt Lucy. What do he & Percie say to each other?
Lovingly your

                  Nettie

Wilder calls dad, daddy, dear dad as soon as he gets sleepy or troublesome
Antoinette Dunbarton
May 22 ' 56
Bangor

Antoinette Dunbarton
May 24 ' 56
Bangor

                                                                                                                      Dunbarton 24 May - 1856

Dearest Isaac-

                The day is done and all have retired to rest but me. When I listen I can just hear the soft breathing of the dear babies - but there's no sound or motion from little Mayo's bed- & no dear Isaac for me to speak to - except as I talk to you on paper, and this I could not resist the inclination to do. It has been very warm yesterday & today. The babies have fretted a good deal. Willie has considerable diarrhea; but they both sleep as well as usual at night, wake at half past four every morning & I get right up and dress me then. I am better myself to day - have had diarrhea attended with some pain ever since you left - and have felt miserably in the mornings - but get

[left-hand side] Love to all - hope very strongly to hear from you tomorrow.
Completed

better before night. Father rode all the way to Hopkinton Thursday to engage an exchange tomorrow with Mr. Angier and this afternoon lunch Rufus Putnam & wife have come to spend the Sabbath. We expect P.M. Charles Marshall from Cranfordsville Ind., will be here also. Father was sorry he was to go to Hopkington, but thought he must go, as he started, got almost there & met Mr. Angier just starting. He seemed rather to choose to go back as he has been from his people considerable of late, so father came home again. We have had a fine thunder shower this afternoon- some hail.

  I long to hear from you - hoped for a letter today. We had one from George. I remailed one to Mother which came by Thursday's mail, from Bangor. I want to know how Mayo behaves- whether he is a good boy does well at table, and at prayers.
Completed

and is kind and good to dear little Percie. I want to know how Lucy is and how you all are. Tell me how Mallie's baby looks too. My eyes begin to grow heavy, and I'll stop.
Sabbath Eve. A sudden change of weather has brought us a very cold day. We have a good warm fire in the sitting room and are all here, Father, mother, uncle, aunt etc. Mr. Marshall was delayed - will be here the present week. So uncle preached all day, and preached better than usual  - really quite good sermons. I do not know how long they will remain. A very full meeting today. The Anti-slavery concert has been held this evening. What startling news from Washington regarding Mr. Sumner. How horrible! O our people seem quite in earnest about it. I went to meting this P.M. and Asenath in the P.M. Willis diarrhea has been troublesome today. I feel
Completed

as if I almost ought to something for him - have not given him anything yet - only boil his milk - this may be all he will need.
(Monday morning) Cold and rainy, chilly and damp enough. Willie washed and dressed and asleep. Wilder asleep in his double dress. Capt. Whipple has been over, an hour or more to see uncle & aunt. Willie & Wilder slept till almost four oclock last night without waking. I rose at half past four as usual and had a bright fire in about a minute. Jennie's ? came for her about eight and she is gone to her school in quite good spirits. May success attend her.

Wilder is really enjoying today in spite of his long dress. He got about a quarter of the way across the long room crowing finely about it. I long to get the short clothes done. Shall miss Jenny a good deal about the babies. Mother says give her love and say that babies have not tasted her tea since you left!

Eve. Mrs. Anderson here to spend the night - also cousin Samuel Putnam. Willie need me. They both need considerable more than usual care - are fretful & want to be held. Love & good night fr. your Nettie.
